questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the deep perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
The root of the penis consists of two crura and one bulb. It is a content of the superficial perineal pouch.

Males Common to both Females

questions.text: A child is diagnosed to have an aneurysmal malformation of a vessel located in the marked structure. Identify the structure and the vessel present in it.
questions.solution:
The area marked "A" is the quadrigeminal cistern, and it contains the great cerebral vein of Galen.

Aneurysmal malformation of the great cerebral vein of Galen is a congenital anomaly occurring due to the persistence of the embryonic prosencephalic vein of Markowski. 

The image below is a CT cerebral angiogram of a vein of Galen malformation and an abnormal falcine sinus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with weakness of shoulder movements. Investigations revealed quadrangular space syndrome. Which of the following nerve is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve is likely to be affected as it is one of the contents of the quadrangular space.

Quadrangular space syndrome is a condition is caused by hypertrophy or fibrosis of the quadrangular space muscles which impinge on the axillary nerve. Patients present with weakness of the shoulder movements.

questions.text: Which space in the neck represented by numbers 1, 2, 3 and 4 in the image below, is known as danger space?
questions.solution:
The danger space of neck is number 3 which extends from the skull base to the diaphragm.

Danger space in neck: The danger space or alar space is the space that is present between the alar fascia and the prevertebral fascia.

The common name originates from the risk that an infection in this space can spread directly to the thorax, and, due to being a space continuous on the left and right, can furthermore allow infection to spread easily to either side.

Boundaries:

  • Anterior: Alar fascia
  • Posterior: Prevertebral fascia
  • Superior: Clivus
  • Inferior: Posterior mediastinum at the level of the diaphragm

Other options :

  • Prevertebral space extends from the base of the skull to the coccyx.
  • Retropharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the tracheal bifurcation.
  • Parapharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the hyoid bone and submandibular gland.

Cervical fascia:

The cervical fascia in the neck consists of superficial fascia and various layers of deep fascia, which encloses several spaces.

The superficial cervical fascia is a zone of loose connective tissue, between the dermis and deep cervical fascia.

The deep cervical fascia includes three layers:

  • The superficial layer of deep cervical fascia also known as investing layer of deep fascia or parotidomasseteric fascia.
  • The middle layer of deep cervical fascia also called pretracheal fascia/ visceral fascia/ buccopharyngeal fascia.
  • The deep layer of deep cervical fascia also called prevertebral fascia. The alar fascia is a layer of fascia, sometimes described as part of the prevertebral fascia, lies in front of it.

Spaces in the neck:

Various fascial planes divide the neck into several spaces, which include

  • Spaces which extend in the entire length of the neck:
    • Prevertebral space
    • Retropharyngeal space
    • Carotid space
  • Spaces in the suprahyoid region of neck:
    • Buccal space
    • Parapharyngeal space
    • Parotid space
    • Pharyngeal mucosal space
    • Masticator space
  • Spaces in the infrahyoid region of the neck
    • Anterior cervical space
    • Posterior cervical space
    • Visceral space

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about blood supply of the oesophagus except:

choices.text: Thoracic part of the oesophagus drains into hemiazygous vein
Cervical part of the oesophagus receives blood supply from inferior thyroid artery
Abdominal part of the oesophagus receives blood supply from right gastric artery
Abdominal part of the oesophagus drains into left gastric vein

questions.solution:
The abdominal part of the oesophagus receives blood supply from the left gastric artery.

Blood supply of the oesophagus:

Arterial supply:

  • Cervical part: Inferior thyroid artery
  • Thoracic part: Bronchial and Oesophageal branches of descending thoracic aorta
  • Abdominal part: Left gastric artery

Venous drainage:

  • Cervical part: Inferior thyroid veins
  • Thoracic part: Azygous veins and hemiazygous veins
  • Abdominal part: Left gastric and upper short gastric veins and to a lesser extent drains into azygous and hemiazygous veins

questions.text: Extra embryonic mesoderm is derived from ____.
questions.solution:
Extra embryonic mesoderm is formed from primary yolk sac.

Extrembryonic mesoderm :

  • A new population of cells appears between inner surface of cytotrophoblast and outer surface of exocoelomic cavity. These cells, derived from primary yolk sac cells, form a fine loose connective tissue called extraembryonic mesoderm, which eventually fills all the space between trophoblast externally and amnion and extracoelomic membrane internally.
  • Large cavities develop in extraembryonic mesoderm , which become confluent, they from a new space known as extrembryonic coelom or chorionic cavity .
  • Extrembryonic mesoderm lining the cytotrophoblast and amnion is called extraembryonic somatopleuric mesoderm , lining covering the yolk sac is exytraembryonic splanchanopleuric mesoderm.

questions.text: A gasteroenterologist is performing an esophagoscopy in a patient with severe acid reflux. At which level will he encounter its diaphragmatic constriction?
questions.solution:
The esophageal hiatus is located at the level of the T10 vertebra, and it forms a normal constriction of the esophagus. It transmits the following:

  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels and
  • Some lymphatic vessels

Clinical significance:

Anatomical constrictions of the esophagus are important landmarks in esophagoscopy. These are 4 in number and located at a distance from the upper incisors as follows:

  1. 15cm - Cricopharyngeus muscle
  2. 22.5cm - Aortic arch
  3. 27.5cm - Left bronchus
  4. 37.5cm - Diaphragmatic opening

questions.text: A 2 week-old neonate developed meningitis following a scalp abscess. What is the likely route of spread?
questions.solution:
The infection has likely spread from the sub-aponeurotic tissue. 

The sub-aponeurotic loose areolar tissue of the scalp is referred to as the dangerous area of the scalp. Infection from this layer can pass into the cranial cavity through small emissary veins, which pass through parietal foramina in the calvaria. It can reach intracranial structures causing meningitis and intracranial abscesses. 

The scalp is a soft tissue that covers the calvaria of the skull. It consists of 5 layers as shown in the image below (mnemonic - SCALP):

questions.text: Identify the type of muscle marked as X in the image below.
questions.solution:
The muscle marked X in the cadaveric image is the pectoralis major, which is a spiral muscle. 

Spiral muscles have fiber architecture as follows:

  • The muscle fibers have a spiral or twisted arrangement. e.g., pectoralis major (sternocostal fibers) and latissimus dorsi that undergo a 180° twist between their medial and lateral attachments.
  • The entire muscle takes a spiral course around a bone. e.g., supinator winds obliquely around the proximal radial shaft.

Cruciate is a type of spiral muscle where two or more planes of muscle fibers are arranged in differing directions. e.g., sternocleidomastoid, masseter and adductor magnus are all partially spiral and cruciate.

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman came with complaints of dull aching pain in the throat and right side of the face. She also frequently gets pain while swallowing associated with earache and headaches. On CT scan, a calcified stylohyoid ligament was seen. This ligament is derived from:
questions.solution:
The stylohyoid ligament is derived from the cartilage of the second pharyngeal arch which is Reichert's cartilage. 

Reichert's cartilage contributes to the development of the following structures:

The dorsal portion forms:

  • Stapes
  • Styloid process of the temporal bone
  • Stylohyoid ligament 

The ventral portion forms:

  • The upper part of the body and the lesser cornu of the hyoid bone.

Note: This condition is called Eagle syndrome. It is a condition associated with the elongation of the styloid process or calcification of the stylohyoid ligament.

These structures can be remembered as 5S's:

  • Stapes
  • Styloid process of the temporal bone
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Smaller (lesser) cornu of the hyoid bone
  • Superior part of the body of the hyoid bone

questions.text: Nuclei present in the floor of IV ventricle in open part of medulla are all except?
questions.solution:
The central gray matter lies beneath the floor of the fourth ventricle at this level.

Passing from medial to lateral, the following important structures:

  1. The hypoglossal nucleus
  2. The dorsal nucleus of the vagus
  3. The nucleus of the tractus solitarius
  4. The medial and inferior vestibular nuclei

The nucleus ambiguus is situated deep in the medullary reticular formation.

questions.text: The first layer of the sole consists of:
questions.solution:
The first layer of the sole consists of abductor hallucis.

The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers. From superficial to deep, the layers are numbered from one to four.

Muscles of the sole of the foot are:

1st layer: This is the superficial layer which includes abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi, and flexor digitorum brevis.

 

2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second layer.

3rd layer: It contains the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis.

4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis longus.

questions.text: All the following muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes except ______.
questions.solution:
All the muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes except palatoglossus. It is derived from the fourth pharyngeal arch.

Hence all the muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except the palatoglossus muscle which is supplied by the pharyngeal plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the limbic system?
questions.solution:
Medial thalamic nuclei are not part of the limbic system. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is a part of the limbic system.

The limbic system controls emotional behavior and is involved in the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory. It consists of both the grey mater and white mater. It is located between the cerebral cortex and the hypothalamus.

Related Pearl: Components of limbic system

questions.text: A mislabeled sample of tissue was sent over to the pathology lab for histopathological examination. On microscopy, a characteristic corpuscle as seen in the image was visualised. Which of the following structures is the sample most likely to be from?
questions.solution:
The sample is most likely to be of the thymus because of the presence of the corpuscle of Hassal as seen in the image above.

These are small rounded structures formed from eosinophilic type VI epithelial reticular cells present in the medulla of the thymus. Each corpuscle has a central core formed by degenerated epithelial cells appearing as pink stained hyaline mass. Around this mass, there is a wall formed by concentrically arranged epithelial cells which stain bright pink in H and E staining.

To determine the magnitude of equilibrium potential.

Equilibrium potential is the membrane potential at which an ion exists in equilibrium across the membrane.

The Nernst equation for Chloride ions is,

Option b: Henderson–Hasselbalch equation is used for the calculation of pH of a buffer solution.

questions.text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which of the following causes relaxation of the mesangial cells?
questions.solution:
cAMP causes relaxation of the mesangial cells. The other agents mentioned in the options cause contraction of the mesangial cells.

Angiotensin II is an important regulator of mesangial contraction, and there are angiotensin II receptors in the glomeruli.

  • Leukotrienes C4 and D4
  • Histamine

Relaxation of mesangial cells:

  • ANP
  • Dopamine
  • PGE2
  • cAMP

questions.text: Pacemaker generating the rhythm for breathing is ________

choices.text: Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla

questions.solution:
Pre-Botzinger complex generates the rhythm for automated breathing.

  • These are also known as pacemaker cells located in the medulla.
  • These are the first set of neurons that initiate inspiration.
  • These neurons discharge rhythmically, and they produce rhythmic discharges in the phrenic motor neurons.

Breathing is under the control of both the following:

  • Voluntary control: Located in the cerebral cortex (via corticospinal tract)
  • Automatic control: Driven by pacemaker cells in the medulla (Pre-Botzinger complex). These activate motor neurons via cervical (Phrenic nerve innervating diaphragm) and thoracic spinal cord (external intercostal muscle).

There is a reciprocal innervation to expiratory and inspiratory muscles in that motor neurons supplying expiratory muscles are inactive when motor neurons supplying inspiratory muscles are active, and vice versa.

 

Inspiration
Initiation Pre-Botzinger complex (Pacemaker cells) in Medulla
Maintenance Apneustic center in lower Pons stimulates Dorsal group of neurons in the medulla
Termination  Apneustic center inhibited by Vagus and Pneumotaxic center

Regulation of expiration: During quiet breathing, expiration is a passive process; there is no firing of neurons. Ventral respiratory group of neurons are involved in forceful expiration like during exercise.

Mnemonic DIVE: Dorsal respiratory group for Inspiration and Ventral respiratory group for Expiration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text: Calculate the ejection fraction from the given left ventricular pressure-volume curve:
questions.solution:
The ejection fraction as calculated from the above volume pressure curve is 60%.

The ejection fraction is defined as the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke.

Thus, EF = Volume ejected / End diastolic volume × 100

The volume ejected can be obtained, by subtracting the end systolic volume from end diastolic volume. Thus,

EF = End diastolic volume (EDV) − End systolic volume (ESV) / End diastolic volume (EDV) × 100

In the above volume pressure curve of left ventricle,

EDV = 130 ml

ESV = 52 ml

Substituting these values in the above equation we get,

EF = (130 − 52 / 130) × 100

 = (3 / 5) × 100

 = 0.6 × 100

 = 60%

Related information:

The ejection fraction is a valuable index of the ventricular function. It is measured by injecting radionuclide-labeled red blood cells and imaging the volume of the blood at the end of diastole and the end of systole (equilibrium radionuclide angiocardiography), or by computed tomography.

The normal left ventricular ejection fraction is 50% to 70%.

In heart failure, ejection fraction may be preserved or reduced,

  • Preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) – also referred to as diastolic heart failure. The heart muscle contracts normally but the ventricles do not relax as they should during ventricular filling (or when the ventricles relax).
  • Reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) – also referred to as systolic heart failure. The heart muscle does not contract effectively and less oxygen-rich blood is pumped out to the body.

LVEF Assessment:

The American college of cardiology (ACC), gives the cardiac function and their corresponding ejection fractions

  • Hyperdynamic = LVEF greater than 70%
  • Normal = LVEF 50% to 70% (midpoint 60%)
  • Mild dysfunction = LVEF 40% to 49% (midpoint 45%)
  • Moderate dysfunction = LVEF 30% to 39% (midpoint 35%)
  • Severe dysfunction = LVEF less than 30%

questions.text: Half-life of T4_____
questions.solution:
The half-life of T4 is 6 - 7 days.

T3 has the shorter half-life of 1 day.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year old man who suffered a head injury in an automobile accident. Identify the pattern of breathing.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Cheyne–Stokes breathing. In this case, the person breathes deeply for a short interval and then breathes slightly or not for an additional interval. This pattern repeats itself about every minute.

It is the most common type of periodic breathing seen most commonly in patients with heart failure and uremia, also seen in patients with brain disease and during sleep in normal individuals.

This increased response occurs apparently due to the disruption of neural pathways that normally inhibit respiration. In such an individual, increased sensitivity to CO2 causes relative hyperventilation, lowering the arterial Pco2. During the resultant apnoea, the arterial Pco2 rises again to normal, but the respiratory mechanisms again over-responds to CO2. Breathing ceases, and the cycle repeats.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia and was prescribed ferrous fumarate tablets for 2 months. Which of the following channels help in the absorption of this iron taken orally into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
The channel that helps in the absorption of the iron into the enterocyte is divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). Transport of iron across the brush border of the intestinal cells in the ferrous form is accomplished by DMT-1, also known as natural resistance-associated macrophage protein type 2 (Nramp 2). 

The mechanism of iron absorption and transport - 

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. This iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1). 

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption. 

The following illustration shows the absorption of iron in the duodenum:

questions.text: The factor responsible for hysteresis is _______
questions.solution:
Surfactant is the factor responsible for hysteresis.

Difference between the curve of inflation (inspiration) and deflation (expiration) in a pressure–volume curve of the lung is termed as hysteresis.  

The alveolar environment and, specifically, the secreted factors that help reduce surface tension and keep alveoli from collapsing, contribute to hysteresis.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is thyroxine - decreased blood glucose. Thyroxine is a diabetogenic hormone leading to an increase in blood glucose levels.

Effects Of Hormones On Carbohydrate Metabolism:  

  • Catecholamines: Activation of glycogen phosphorylase and therefore glycogenolysis occurs. Hepatic glucose output is increased, producing hyperglycemia.  
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids from the adrenal cortex elevate blood glucose by stimulating gluconeogenesis and inhibiting glucose utilization by the cells.  
  • Growth Hormone: The effects of growth hormone are partly direct and partly mediated via IGF-I (Insulin-like Growth Factor-I). The growth hormone mobilizes FFA from adipose tissue, thus favoring ketogenesis. It decreases glucose uptake into some tissues (“anti-insulin action”), increases hepatic glucose output, and may decrease tissue binding of insulin.

Note: Infusing catecholamine (Epinephrine) mainly promotes glycogenolysis and it is also associated with enhanced rates of aerobic glycolysis in skeletal muscles during exercise (resulting in adenosine triphosphate production).

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding calcium homeostasis?

choices.text: 90% of calcium is filtered from the glomerulus
Calcium is reabsorbed mainly from the late distal convoluted tubule (DCT)
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) promotes calcium reabsorption from the renal tubules
Calcitonin promotes action of parathyroid hormone

questions.solution:
PTH promotes the reabsorption of calcium from the renal tubules. 

Option A: About 41 percent of the plasma calcium is bound to plasma proteins and is therefore not filtered by the glomerular capillaries. The rest of the calcium is filtered through the glomeruli into the renal tubules. 

Option B: Of the filtered calcium, approximately 90 percent is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, loops of Henle, and early distal tubules. However, when calcium levels are low and PTH levels rise, PTH promotes calcium reabsorption from the later DCT. 

Option D: Calcitonin tends to decrease plasma calcium concentration and, in general, has effects opposite to those of PTH.

questions.text: Purely depolarizing cells in optic pathway are ______
questions.solution: The responses of the rods, cones, and horizontal cells are hyperpolarizing, and the responses of the bipolar cells are either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing, whereas amacrine cells produce purely depolarizing potential.

questions.text: The transpulmonary pressure is the pressure difference between _______
questions.solution:
Transpulmonary pressure is intra-alveolar pressure minus intrapleural pressure. (Mnemonic TAP: Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Pleural pressure)

It is the pressure difference between that in the alveoli and that on the outer surfaces of the lungs, and it is a measure of the elastic forces in the lungs that tend to collapse the lungs at each instant of respiration, called the recoil pressure.

questions.text: Regarding the two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis which of the following is true?

choices.text: FSH and LH inhibits the release of estrogen and progesterone
FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells
FSH stimulates estrogen while LH inhibits estrogen
FSH feedback inhibits hypothalamus while LH feedback inhibits pituitary

questions.solution:
The two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis:

  • Estradiol synthesis requires the contribution of two distinct cell types:
    • The theca and granulosa cells within the follicle and
    • The theca-lutein and granulosa lutein cells within the corpus luteum
  • The follicular theca cells, under the control of LH, produce androgens that diffuse to the follicular granulosa cells, where they are converted to estrogens via an FSH-supported aromatization reaction. The granulosa cells cannot convert progesterone to androstenedione because of the lack of the enzyme 17α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: A patient with cardiac output 5L/min and body surface area 1.7m2. What will be the cardiac index (L/min/m2)?
questions.solution:
Cardiac index  is the cardiac output per minute per square meter of body surface.

Cardiac Index = Cardiac output / body surface area.

Therefore Cardiac index = 5L/min /1.7m2= 2.94 L

questions.text: PDGF acts through which of the following signaling pathways?
questions.solution:
PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) acts through the activation of tyrosine kinases.

All growth factors that foster the multiplication or development of various types of cells act through the activation of tyrosine kinases.

questions.text: Which of the following tools of recombinant DNA technology is incorrectly paired with its use?

choices.text: DNA polymerase - copies DNA sequences in the polymerase chain reaction
DNA ligase - enzyme that cuts DNA, creating sticky ends
Reverse transcriptase - production of cDNA from mRNA

questions.solution:
DNA ligase is not paired correctly with its use for cutting DNA and creating sticky ends. DNA ligase joins the adjacent nucleotides in a covalent linkage.

Restriction endonucleases cut DNA at specific sites creating sticky ends.

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease type I  is due to a defect in _____.
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) type I is due to impaired alpha-Ketoacid decarboxylase component of BCKAD (branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase) complex, leading to defective decarboxylation reaction and the formation of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) and their toxic byproducts (keto-acids) in blood and urine.

A peculiar odor (burnt sugar) is found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Note: Amino-acids and disorders of their metabolism are invariably being asked in NEET as well as in AIIMS examinations.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporter is specific to the transport of fructose from the intestine to enterocytes?
questions.solution:
Glucose transporter specific to the transport of fructose from the intestine to enterocytes is GLUT 5. It is present in small intestine, testis, and sperm, and it primarily transports fructose.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS)?
questions.solution:
The most common MPS is Sanfilippo (MPS III), followed by Hurler and Hunter’s.

Sanfilippo disease makes up a genetically heterogeneous but clinically similar group of 4 recognized types.

  • The enzyme deficient is involved in Heparan sulfate
  • Onset of symptoms: between 2 and 6 years of age.
  • It is characterized by severe CNS involvement with a mild somatic involvement, this disproportionate involvement of CNS is a unique feature of MPS III.
  • Other features include sleep disturbances, aggressive behavior problems, hirsutism.
  • Stem cell therapy is not beneficial and no enzyme replacement therapy is useful.

Note: corneal clouding is absent in Hunters and Sanfilippo.

questions.text: HMP shunt can occur at all of the following sites except:
questions.solution:
HMP shunt pathway can not occur in muscles because muscle tissue is deficient in glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase, the rate-limiting enzyme in the oxidative phase of the pathway.

HMP shunt pathway takes place in the following:

  • Liver
  • Adipose tissue
  • Adrenal cortex
  • Thyroid
  • Erythrocytes
  • Testis
  • Lactating mammary glands

Given below is the HMP shunt pathway.

questions.text: Which among the following enzymes can utilize both NAD+ and NADP+?
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase is unusual in that it can use either NAD+ or NADP+ as a coenzyme.

NAD+ is used primarily in oxidative deamination (the simultaneous loss of ammonia coupled with the oxidation of the carbon skeleton).

NADPH is used in reductive amination (the simultaneous gain of ammonia coupled with the reduction of the carbon skeleton).

questions.text: Which of the following situations does the red line in the following graph depict?
questions.solution:
The red line in the graph represents an enzymatic reaction with a noncompetitive inhibitor. 

The above graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/v0 (v0 - initial velocity) is plotted versus 1/[S] ([S] - substrate concentration) and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors. The x-intercept represents -1/Km while the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax. 

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged. Hence the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at the same -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

Note: An allosteric inhibitor alters the conformation of an enzyme upon binding. Enzymes affected by allosteric inhibitors exhibit a sigmoid, not hyperbolic, relationship between V0 and [S].

questions.text: What is a primary transcript?

choices.text: RNA product synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction
RNA product synthesized in the 3′-5′ direction
DNA product synthesized in the 3′-5′ direction
DNA product synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction

questions.solution:
The RNA product, which is synthesized in the 5′-3′ direction, is the primary transcript. The primary transcripts are generated by RNA polymerase II.

The longest primary transcript is produced by the dystrophin gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a glycolipid?
questions.solution:
Cerebroside is an example of a glycolipid.

A glycolipid is a complex lipid containing a carbohydrate. Cerebrosides consist of sphingosine, a fatty acid and a single sugar linked to sphingosine. Thus, they are glycolipids. Cerebrosides are found predominantly in the brain and peripheral nervous tissue, with high concentrations in the myelin sheath.

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are components of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex, except
questions.solution:
Pyruvate kinase is not a component of the Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) enzyme complex.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to Acetyl-CoA.

The three enzyme components are:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

The Cofactors are:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is : Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Clinical aspects:

  • Arsenite and mercuric ions react with the -SH groups of lipoic acid and inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • Dietary deficiency of thiamin inhibits PDH eg. Chronic alcoholics may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis.
  • Patients with inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency present with lactic acidosis, particularly after a glucose load and neurological disturbances.

Note : Pyruvate kinase catalyses the last step of glycolysis ie- transfering phosphate group from phosphoenol pyruvate to ADP forming pyruvate and ATP respectively.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe breathlessness with wheezing. Her peak expiratory flow rate is reduced significantly. Which of the following enzymes is important for the pathogenesis of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset of severe breathlessness and wheezing with a reduced peak expiratory flow rate is suggestive of acute exacerbation of asthma. 5-lipoxygenase enzyme is important for the pathogenesis of this condition. 

Acute exacerbation of asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction due to chemicals mediators like leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4 etc.). Leukotrienes are produced from the breakdown of arachidonic acid by 5-lipoxygenase via the lipoxygenase pathway. 

Leukotrienes are eicosanoic acid derivatives formed in leukocytes, mast cells, platelets, and macrophages. They are potent constrictors of the bronchial airway. Leukotrienes also cause increased vascular permeability and activation and attraction of leukocytes. Thus, they are involved in many inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions, such as asthma.

questions.text: What is the total number of double bonds present in arachidonic acid?
questions.solution:
Arachidonic acid contains 4 double bonds in its structure. 

Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acid (PUFA). It has 4 double bonds present in a cis configuration. It is present in the phospholipids of cell membranes and is the precursor of prostanoids such as prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes.

questions.text: Which  of the following is not a hepatic porphyria?
questions.solution:
Erythropoietic protoporphyria is not a type of hepatic porphyria. 

Porphyrias are classified into erythropoietic and hepatic porphyrias, based on the location of accumulation of heme pathway intermediates:

  1. Erythropoietic porphyrias:
    1. The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
    2. They are characterized by cutaneous symptoms and appear in early childhood.
    3. Examples: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, erythropoietic protoporphyria, X-linked protoporphyria
  2. Hepatic porphyrias:
    1. The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
    2. Acute hepatic porphyrias are characterised by neurologic symptoms and present acutely. Examples: Acute intermittent porphyria, hereditary coproporphyria, variegate porphyria, ALA dehydratase deficient porphyria
    3. Chronic hepatic porphyrias present in adulthood with photosensitivity. Example: Porphyria cutanea tarda

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: Muscle cannot release glucose from glycogen because of the deficiency of which of the following  enzymes?
questions.solution:
Muscles cannot release glucose into the blood due to the absence of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase.

Glucose-6-phosphatase is present in the lumen of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes. Hence, hepatocytes can convert glucose-6-phosphate into glucose and release glycogen-derived glucose into the blood in order to maintain blood glucose levels stable, until gluconeogenesis kicks in. 

However, myocytes lack the enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase. As a result, glucose-6-phosphate cannot be dephosphorylated and released into the blood. Muscle glycogen provides a readily available source of glucose-1-phosphate for glycolysis within the muscle itself.

Defects in the enzyme or glucose-6-phosphate transporter (GLUT 7) can cause type I glycogen storage disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of RNA polymerase II?
questions.solution:
Synthesis of rRNA is not a function of RNA polymerase II. This is done by RNA polymerase I

questions.text: Which of the following are enantiomers?
questions.solution:
D-mannose and L-mannose are enantiomers. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other.

The designation of a sugar isomer as the D- or L- form is determined by its spatial relationship to the parent compound of the carbohydrates, that is, the three-carbon sugar glyceraldehyde. The orientation of the —H and —OH groups around the penultimate carbon atom determines whether the sugar belongs to the D- or L- series. When the —OH group on the penultimate carbon atom of the sugar is on the right side, then the sugar is designated as a D- isomer. When the –OH group is on the left, it is an L-isomer.

Naturally occurring monosaccharides are D-sugars and naturally occurring amino acids are L-isomers. Racemase enzyme interconverts between D and L isomers.

Examples of enantiomers include D-glucose and L-glucose, D-fructose and L-fructose and D-mannose and L-mannose

questions.text: In a patient with a positive Casoni's skin test,  which of the following infections will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s skin test is done in patients with hydatid disease.

It is an immediate hypersensitivity reaction (type I). Sterile hydatid fluid is injected (0.2 mL) intradermally in one arm and an equal volume of saline as control is injected in the other arm. In a positive reaction, a large wheal appears within half an hour. A secondary reaction consisting of edema and induration appears after 8 hours. 

This test is abandoned now due to non-specificity and has been supplemented by serological tests.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

The table below shows some of the important skin tests used in the diagnosis of parasitic infections.

questions.text: Which of the following protozoan parasites is found in the lumen of the human small intestine?
questions.solution:
Image 2 shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia, which is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the human small intestine. It lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum.

Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but are present in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include:

  • Isospora belli
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Sarcocystis hominis

Other options:

Options A and C: Entamoeba histolytica and Balantidium coli are found in the human large intestine.

Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract.

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Balantidium coli.

 

The image given below shows the trophozoite of Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: The following colony morphology on blood agar is indicative of
questions.solution:
The given image shows the frosted glass appearance of the colonies, which is characteristic of Bacillus anthracis.

Bacillus anthracis is the etiologic agent of anthrax—a common disease of livestock and, occasionally, of humans—and the only obligate pathogen within the genus Bacillus. It is a gram-positive, endospore-forming (non-bulging spores), rod-shaped bacterium. Culture characteristics are as follows:

  • On agar, irregularly round colonies are formed, 2 to 3 mm in diameter, raised, dull, opaque, greyish white, with a frosted glass appearance.
  • Under the low-power microscope, the edge of the colony is composed of long, interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling locks of matted hair, called Medusa head appearance.
  • On gelatin stab, they appear as inverted fir tree appearance.
  • On solid media with penicillin, they show a string of pearls appearance in culture smear.

Bamboo stick appearance on Gram staining (image):

questions.text: Which of the following is a nonstructural gene of HIV?
questions.solution:
The tat gene (trans-activating gene) is a non-structural gene. 

HIV has structural and non-structural genes: 

  • Structural genes- Genes coding for structural protiens:  
    • gag- Codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24  
    • env- Codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41
    • pol- Codes for enzymes: Polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease and endonuclease
  • Non-structural and regulatory genes:
    • tat- Trans-activating gene
    • nef- Negative factor gene
    • rev- Regulator of virus gene
    • vif- Viral infectivity factor gene
    • vpu- (only in HIV-1) and vpx (only in HIV-2)
    • vpr- Stimulates only the promoter region of the virus
    • LTR- Long terminal repeat sequences

questions.text: All of the following Hemophilus species require both Factors X and V  except_______.
questions.solution:
Hemophilus parahemolyticus requires only factor V for its growth. It does not require factors X.

Hemophilus species requiring both factors X and V: (Mnemonic to remember: HAI)

  • H. hemolyticus
  • H. aegypticus
  • H. influenzae

Factor V- It refers to the co-enzyme, NAD. It is heat-labile (destroyed at 120°C in a few minutes) and present inside RBC.

Factor X- It refers to Hemin. It is heat stable and is present in the blood.

Species X factor requirement V factor requirement
H. influenzae + +
H. aegypticus + +
H. ducreyi + -
H. parainfluenza − +
H. haemolyticus + +
H. parahaemolyticus − +

questions.text: In a bacterial growth curve, the period in which maximum cell size is obtained is
questions.solution:
The following image shows bacterial growth curve, characterized by an initial lag phase, followed by log phase or exponential growth phase, then reaching a stationary phase followed by phase of decline.

  • A - Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence by the end of lag phase, maximum cell size is obtained
  • B - Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time
  • C - Stationary phase: The viable count remains stationary as an equilibrium exists between the dying and the newly formed cells.
  • D - Phase of decline: Cell population decreases in this phase due to cell death.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Congenital zikavirus infection causes microcephaly, not macrocephaly. 

Zikavirus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, sexual and blood-borne transmission is also observed. Humans are the only reservoir. Vertical transmission from an infected mother can occur throughout gestation and commonly results in fetal death. Other complications include neural tube defects, sensorineural deafness, microcephaly, and ocular abnormalities.

Affected adults present with fever, arthralgia, myalgia, and rash, similar to dengue fever. Non-purulent conjunctivitis and palatal petechiae may also be seen. Complications though rare include Guillain-Barre syndrome, leukopenia, encephalitis, and thrombocytopenic purpura. It can persist in the testes for up to 160 days, making sexual transmission possible during this period.

It is diagnosed by RT-PCR which detects viral RNA. There are no curative or preventive antivirals or licensed vaccines available as of yet.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding drug resistance?

choices.text: In mutational drug resistance one drug resistance is seen at a time
Virulence is decreased in transferable resistance
Drug combinations can prevent Mutational drug resistance
High degree of resistance is seen in transferable drug resistance

questions.solution:
• Virulence is not decreased in transferable drug resistance.
  • Transferable drug resistance is widely seen in various pathogenic and commensal bacteria of humans.
  • The transfer can be effected readily in vitro, but in the normal gut, it is inhibited by factors such as Bile salts, anaerobic conditions, and alkaline pH.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Mutational and Transferable Drug Resistance

Multiple drug resistance

High degree resistance

High dose ineffective

Drug combinations can prevent

Drug combinations cannot prevent

Resistance does not spread

Spreads to same or different species

Mutants may be defective

Not defective

Virulence may be low

Virulence not decreased

questions.text: Which of the toxins produced by clostridium species is the basis of Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
α-toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens forms the basis of Nagler's reaction.

The α-toxin of C.perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C.perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: An immunologist is conducting an experiment to understand precipitation reactions. He notes that on adding excessive amount of antigen to a serum sample containing small amount of antibodies, the amount of precipitate formed is less, compared to adding smaller amount of antigen to the same sample. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
This phenomenon is called post–zone phenomenon because it has excessive antigen in the test system, leading to weak or even absent precipitation. 

Lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies.

  • Prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation- false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence- antigen, and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post–zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation) 

 

Flocculation: Instead of sedimenting, precipitate remains suspended as floculus.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, fever, and vomiting. On examination, you observe the following. He is diagnosed with herpangina. Which group of viruses causes the same?
questions.solution:
The given image shows palatal ulcers in herpangina. It is caused by the coxsackievirus A, a large subgroup of the enteroviruses.

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by grayish- white papulovesicular lesions on an erythematous base that ulcerate. These are present on:

  • Soft palate
  • Anterior pillars of tonsils
  • Uvula
  • Posterior oropharynx

It is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackievirus A infection in children, but it can also be caused by coxsackievirus B, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71.

Treatment is usually only supportive, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week.

questions.text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years.  She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Recurrent rhinitis, chronic nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage, multiple ethmoidal polyps and the microscopic appearance of conical vesicles with conidia over two-thirds of the vesicle is suggestive of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus.

Aspergillus spp. can lead to the following types of sinusitis:

  1. Acute invasive sinusitis: It affects immunocompromised patients. They present with fever, nasal or facial discomfort, blocked nose and bloody nasal discharge. Pale, dusky or necrotic tissue will be present within the sinuses.
  2. Chronic aspergillus sinusitis:
    • Fungal ball of sinus: The maxillary sinus, most commonly, is filled with an aspergillus ball. No tissue invasion is present.
    • Chronic invasive sinusitis: There is slow destruction of the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with bone destruction and localised spread. Patients present with chronic nasal discharge and blockage, loss of the sense of smell and persistent headache. Involvement of the orbit results in proptosis and blindness.
    • Chronic granulomatous sinusitis: Patients present with facial swelling and unilateral proptosis. Biopsied tissue shows granulomatous (not necrotic) reaction.
  3. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis: Patients present with chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On microscopy, eosinophilia and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen.

On microscopic examination of the sinus or polyp tissue, hyaline, septate, acute branching hyphae of Aspergillus spp. can be seen. The various species can be differentiated based on the appearance of the conidiophores. In Aspergillus fumigatus, the vesicle is conical. Phialides are arranged in a single row. Conidia arise from the upper two-thirds of the vesicle and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus flavus has a globular vesicle. Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option C: Aspergillus niger has a globular-shaped vesicle. Phialides are in two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.

Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores (brush or broom appearance).

questions.text: A microbiologist studying Vibrio cholera added sulphuric acid to a 24-hour peptone culture of the organism and a reddish-pink color developed. Which of the following is true about the test he performed?

choices.text: It is known as methyl red test
A nitrosoindole compound is formed giving it the red colour
The red colour is obtained due to pigment production by the bacteria
The red colour is obtained due to acid & gas production by Vibrio

questions.solution:
The test described here is the 'cholera red reaction' given by Vibrio cholera. When few drops of concentrated sulphuric acid are added to a 24-hour peptone water culture, a reddish-pink colour develops due to the formation of nitrosoindole. Vibrio cholerae reduce nitrates to nitrites and convert tryptophan to indole. These two properties contribute to the cholera red reaction. 

Other options:

Option A: The methyl red (MR) test is used to detect the production of sufficient acid during the fermentation of glucose by bacteria. It is used to classify Enterobacteriacae.

Option C: Vibrio cholera does not produce any colored pigment.

Option D: Vibrio ferments carbohydrates leading to production of acid but no gas.

questions.text: All are true about Streptococcus pyogenes except

choices.text: Streptolysin O is active in reduced state
Streptokinase is produced from Group  A β-hemolytic streptococci
Pyrogenic toxin A is plasmid mediated

questions.solution:
Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin A is not plasmid mediated, it is phage mediated.

Other options:

Streptodornase also called as deoxyribonuclease( DNAse ) is a virulence factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. It causes depolymerization of DNA, which helps to liquefy the thick pus and is responsible for the thin serous character of streptococcal exudate. Four antigenically distinct DNAases a, b, c, and d have been recognized, of which type b is the most antigenic in human beings.

Streptolysin O is so called because it is oxygen labile. It is inactive in the oxidized form and active in the reduced state.

Streptokinase (SK) is a plasminogen activator produced by many strains of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding bacterial cell wall?

choices.text: Cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria is thicker than that of Gram-negative bacteria
Teichoic acid is present in cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria
Region II of LPS is core polysaccharide
LPS is responsible for O antigen specificity of gram negative bacteria

questions.solution:
Cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria

  • Peptidoglycan layer is thicker (15–80 nm) than gram negative bacteria (7.5–10nm)
  • Teichoic acid is present

Cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria

  • LPS present is responsible for endotoxic activity and O antigen specificity
  • It has 3 regions:
    • Region I - O polysaccharide determining O antigen specificity
    • Region II – core polysaccharide
    • Region III – Lipid A responsible for pyrogenicity, lethal effect, tissue necrosis, anticomplementary activity
  • Outer membrane
  • Lipoprotein
  • Peptidoglycan

questions.text: A patient has chronic cough with occasional blood in the sputum. He has a history of significant weight loss and night sweats. Which of the following media cannot be used to culture the organism causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough and hemoptysis with a concurrent history of significant weight loss and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. McLeod's medium is not used to culture M. tuberculosis. It is a selective medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis include:

  • Solid- Loeffler's medium is a serum-containing solid medium used for the culture of M. tuberculosis. Other solid media used include Lowenstein- Jensen medium, Dorset medium, Tarshis medium, and Pawlowsky's medium.
  • Liquid- Middlebrook’s media are used for the preparation of antigens and vaccines and in sensitivity testing.  Other examples of liquid mycobacterial culture media include Dubos' medium, Sula's medium and Sauton's medium.
  • Automated culture methods: 
    • BACTEC 460- uses radioisotopes for detection
    • BacT alert- colorimetric method of detection
    • BACTEC MGIT- fluorometric detection method.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding von Magnus phenomenon?

choices.text: Virus has low hemagglutination and high infectivity
von Magnus phenomenon is not seen in Influenza virus
Virus has high hemagglutination and high infectivity
Virus yield has high hemagglutination but low infectivity

questions.solution:
von Magnus phenomenon: If the yield of a virus has a high hemagglutinin titer, but low infectivity, then it is called von Magnus phenomenon.

  • It is seen when incomplete viruses are formed due to defective assembly during replication of viruses; hence, they may not be infective.
  • Generation of incomplete viruses is seen in large proportion, when cells are infected with a high dose of the influenza virus.
  • It was first observed by Preben von Magnus in influenza viruses, after the serial passage of virus in undiluted allantoic fluid in eggs.

questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic molar tooth colonies of Actinomyces species.

They are seen after 72 hours growth on brain-heart infusion agar.

questions.text: You received a stool sample of a patient suspected to have dysentery in the microbiology lab.  On microscopy, you observe the structures shown in the image. What other findings you will expect to see in this stool sample?

choices.text: RBCs as discrete or in rouleaux

questions.solution:
The given image is showing erythrophagocytosis (trophozoite with ingested RBCs) and this in the stool sample of a patient with features of dysentery is indicative of amoebic dysentery. The other stool microscopic finding seen in amoebic dysentery is Charcot-Leyden crystals.

The ingested erythrocytes appear as dark inclusions. Erythrophagocytosis is the only characteristic that can be used to morphologically differentiate E. histolytica from the nonpathogenic entamoeba.

Amoebic dysentery: Clinically, it has an insidious onset with localized abdominal tenderness. Tenesmus, toxicity, and fever are absent. Under microscopy, RBCs are clumped, yellowish-brown in color. Charcot-Leyden crystals and eosinophils are present.

Charcot-Leyden crystals are diamond-shaped, clear, and refractile structures that may be seen in stool specimens under microscopy and represent breakdown products of eosinophils.

The below image shows Charcot-Leyden crystals:

questions.text: Which of the following methods of antibiotic susceptibility testing cannot be used to calculate the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug?
questions.solution:
Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cannot be calculated using Kirby-Bauer's disk diffusion method and Stokes disk diffusion method as they are semi-quantitative methods.

MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism. Methods to determine MIC include:

  • Tube dilution method
  • Agar dilution method
  • E-test method

World Antimicrobial Awareness Week, Nov 18-24 2022, is a global campaign that is celebrated annually to improve awareness and understanding of antimicrobial resistance and encourage best practices among the public. The theme for this year is “Preventing Antimicrobial Resistance Together” to encourage the prudent use of antimicrobials and to strengthen preventive measures addressing antimicrobial resistance

questions.text: The bodies shown in the below image are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lewy body. Lewy bodies may be found in the remaining neurons present in the substantia nigra in cases of Parkinson’s disease.

These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions. They have a dense core, surrounded by a pale halo. On ultrastructural examination, Lewy bodies consist of fine filaments, composed of α-synuclein and other proteins, including neurofilaments and ubiquitin. The other major histologic finding is the presence of Lewy neurites that also contain aggregated α-synuclein.

The microscopic feature of Parkinson's disease is pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus. This occurs due to the loss of pigmented, catecholaminergic neurons in these regions associated with gliosis.

Other options

Option A- Pick's disease is a type of front temporal lobar degeneration. The surviving neurons show a characteristic swelling (Pick cells), and others contain Pick bodies, cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. 

The below image shows Pick bodies (marked with asterisks).

Option C- Microscopy of Huntington's disease shows loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus, especially in the tail and in portions nearer the ventricle.

Option D- Important microscopic features of Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of dilated, tortuous axons and dendritic processes. They are present around an amyloid core. Neurofibrillary tangles are tau-containing bundles of filaments in the cytoplasm of the neurons. They can be elongated, flame-shaped, or may be rounded. (globose tangles)

The below image on the right top shows neuritic plaques and on the left bottom shows the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes  Small, bland vegetations, usually attached to the line of closure of the valve leaflets?
questions.solution: Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) usually causes small, bland vegetations, usually attached at the line of closure of valve leaflets.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified protein derivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears as follows.  Which of the following does this represent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside. 

Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: What is the most common mutation identified in patients with autosomal dominant hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Mutations of the gene coding for ankyrin are the most common cause of autosomal dominant hereditary spherocytosis.

The following mutations have been identified in hereditary spherocytosis:

Autosomal dominant (more common):

  • Ankyrin - most common
  • Band 3
  • β-Spectrin

Autosomal recessive:

  • α-Spectrin
  • Band 4.2

Missense mutations of band 3 protein result in stomatocytosis. Stomatocytes are RBCs with a mouth-shaped area of central pallor, as shown below. RBCs acquire the shape of a uniconcave cup due to decreased cell volume or decreased membrane surface area.

Some mutations of the band 3 gene are clinically asymptomatic but protective against Plasmodium falciparum.

questions.text: In a patient with reactive systemic amyloidosis, which of the following proteins are likely to get deposited in the tissues?
questions.solution:
There is the deposition of AA proteins in reactive systemic amyloidosis (secondary amyloidosis).

In inflammatory states, there is a release of IL-1 and IL-6, which act on the liver cells. The liver increases the production of SAA (serum amyloid-associated) proteins which circulate bound to high-density lipoproteins. This gives rise to AA proteins, which get deposited in tissues causing reactive systemic amyloidosis or secondary amyloidosis.

The most common sites are the kidney and heart.

It is usually seen secondary to:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (most common)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Chronic osteomyelitis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Malignancies - renal cell cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with right iliac fossa pain. Imaging shows the presence of an ileocaecal mass. Biopsy of the mass shows a starry sky pattern. What is the translocation involved in this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and biopsy findings are suggestive of Burkitt lymphoma and the translocation involved is t(8;14).

Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8. 

The classic t(8;14)(q24;q32) reciprocal translocation results in the transposition of the c-myc proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 with one of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) genes on chromosome 14. This results in activation of the c-myc gene and is considered responsible for tumor proliferation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of low-grade fever, dry cough, and progressive dyspnea. Examination reveals the following painless skin lesion. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lung biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?

choices.text: Anergy to common skin test antigens

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the lesion of lupus pernio point towards sarcoidosis. It is a multisystemic disease characterized by polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia.

Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.

Immunological abnormalities include:

  • Polyclonal hyperglobulinemia
  • A CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5
  • T- cell expansion and macrophage activation
  • Impaired dendritic cell function
  • Anergy to common skin tests.

The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:

  • B/L hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Non-caseating granulomas
  • Lupus pernio
  • Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis)

Syndromes associated with sarcoidosis are:

  • Mikulicz syndrome - sarcoidosis combined with uveoparotid involvement
  • Lofgren's syndrome - acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy

The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma.

The image below shows stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.

The image below shows laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins known as Schaumann bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.

questions.text: You are conducting the autopsy of a patient who passed away following myocardial infarction. What would be the earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient?
questions.solution:
The earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient is the waviness of myocardial fibres. This is seen within ½-4 hours at the border of the infarct.

These changes are a result of the forceful contractions of viable fibres. The contractions cause stretching and buckling of immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres.

Myocyte vacuolization or myocytolysis may also be seen in the infarct margins. It is due to the accumulation of salt and water in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Such myocytes are viable but poorly contractile.

The image below shows microscopic features of myocardial infarction showing wavy myocardial fibres. There are wavy fibres that are elongated and narrow, as compared with normal fibres. The widened spaces between the dead fibres contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.

Related Pearl: The Temporal Evolution of the Morphologic Changes in Acute MI

Microscopy features

LM: None

LM: Usually none; variable waviness of fibers at border

questions.text: Identify the cell in the given peripheral blood smear and the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease

questions.solution:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.

Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye.

Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes.

Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include:

  • Anaemia of renal disease (uremia)
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artefact

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

questions.text: which among the following statements regarding emphysema is false:

choices.text: Centriacinar emphysema is the most common form.
panacinar emphysema underlies many cases of spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults
panacinar is involvement of only from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.
Centriacinar emphysema occurs predominantly in heavy smokers, often in association with chronic bronchitis

questions.solution:
Distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema emphysema probably underlies many cases of spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults

Emphysema is classified into four major types: (1) centriacinar, (2) panacinar, (3) paraseptal, and (4) irregular.

  • Centriacinar (centrilobular) emphysema
    • Centriacinar emphysema is the most common form.
    • In this type of emphysema, the central or proximal parts of the acini, formed by respiratory bronchioles, are affected, whereas distal alveoli are spared. Thus, both emphysematous and normal airspaces exist within the same acinus and lobule.
    • The lesions are more common and usually more severe in the upper lobes, particularly in the apical segments.
    • Inflammation around bronchi and bronchioles is common.
    • In severe centriacinar emphysema, the distal acinus may also be involved, making differentiation from panacinar emphysema difficult.
    • Centriacinar emphysema occurs predominantly in heavy smokers, often in association with chronic bronchitis (COPD). 
  • Panacinar (panlobular) emphysema
    • In this type, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli.
    • The prefix “pan” refers to the entire acinus, not the entire lung.
    • In contrast to centriacinar emphysema, panacinar emphysema tends to occur more commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung, and it is usually most severe at the bases.
    • This type of emphysema is associated with α1 deficiency.
  • Distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema
    • In this type, the proximal portion of the acinus is normal, and the distal part is predominantly involved. The emphysema is more striking adjacent to the pleura, along the lobular connective tissue septa, and at the margins of the lobules.
    • It occurs adjacent to areas of fibrosis, scarring, or atelectasis and is usually more severe in the upper half of the lungs.
    • The characteristic findings are of multiple, continuous, enlarged airspaces from less than 0.5 cm to more than 2.0 cm in diameter, sometimes forming cystlike structures.
    • This type of emphysema probably underlies many cases of spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults
  • Airspace enlargement with fibrosis (irregular emphysema)
    • Irregular emphysema, so named because the acinus is irregularly involved, is almost invariably associated with scarring. In most instances, it occurs in small foci and is clinically insignificant.

Pathogenesis

  • TGFB gene exhibits polymorphisms that influence susceptibility to the development of COPD by regulating the response of mesenchymal cells to injury. For example, with certain polymorphisms, mesenchymal cell response to TGF-β signalling is reduced, which in turn
  • Results in inadequate repair of elastin injury caused by inhaled toxins.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), especially MMP-9 and MMP-12, have also been shown to have a pathogenic role in emphysema.
  • MMP-9 gene polymorphisms and higher levels of both MMP-9 and MMP-12 have been found in some emphysema patients.

questions.text: What is the normal value of y/x in the following representation?
questions.solution:
In the above image, y/x denotes the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. This is called as Reid index and it is normally 0.4. 

It is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus
  • Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia
  • Inflammation
Difference between clinical presentation of emphysema and chronic bronchitis:
 

Predominant Bronchitis

Late; scanty sputum

questions.text: Which of the following receptors recognize fungi?
questions.solution:
C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

The various classes of innate immune receptors are as follows:

 Receptors Location Function
Toll-like receptors Plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles

Important TLRs and molecules recognised:

  • TLR2 - peptidoglycan of gram + bacteria, lipopolysaccharide of Leptospira
  • TLR3 - dsRNA viruses
  • TLR4Q - Chlamydia and lipopolysaccharide
NOD-like receptors Cytosol of immune cells and epithelial cells
  • Recognise substances from necrotic cells and microbial products
  • Signals via inflammasome which activates caspase and IL-1
C-type lectin receptors  Plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells
  • Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi
RIG-like receptors Cytosol of most cell types
  • Detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of infected cells
  • Stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines
  • Recognize short bacterial peptides containing N-formyl methionyl residues and stimulate chemotaxis
Mannose receptors Plasma membrane of macrophages, immature dendritic cells, and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells
  • Detect microbial sugars (which often contain terminal mannose residues) and induce phagocytosis of the microbes

Mannose receptor is a soluble pattern-recognition receptor. All the others are surface pattern-recognition receptors.

questions.text: Pseudo-inclusions are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Invaginations of the cytoplasm may give the appearance of intranuclear inclusions (“pseudo-inclusions”) or intranuclear grooves in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Nuclear features of papillary carcinoma of thyroid

  • Nuclear overlapping
  • Ground-glass appearance(Orphan Annie nuclei)
  • Nuclear grooving
  • Nuclear crowding
  • Dusty chromatin
  • Pale chromatin
  • Intranuclear inclusion bodies,

 The diagnosis of papillary carcinoma can be made on the basis of these nuclear features, even in the absence of papillary architecture.

Image: Pseudoinclusions in papillary carcinoma

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions is associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency?
questions.solution:
ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease which degrades very high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation.

TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small blood vessels.

Features of TTP include:

  • Fever
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Transient neurologic deficits
  • Renal failure

Related Pearl: Differences between TTP and HUS
