questions.text: Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of chronic pyelonephritis.

Histopathological features of chronic pyelonephritis are:

  • Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization)
  • Chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis in the cortex and medulla
  • Periglomerular fibrosis
  • Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), usually several years after the scarring has occurred and often in the absence of continued infection or persistent vesicoureteral reflux

questions.text:
Vasculitis that involves capillaries is______.
A. Buerger disease
B. Behcet disease
C. Leucocytoclastic vasculitis
D. Churg-Strauss syndrome
questions.solution:
Vasculitis affecting the capillaries are leukocytoclastic vasculitis, Behcet disease, and Churg–Strauss syndrome.

*Note - MICROSCOPIC POLYANGITIS (MPA) also affects small vessels such as capillaries, venules and  arterioles.

Related Pearl: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with non-sense mutation?
questions.solution:
A non-sense mutation is seen in β0 thalassemia.

A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA are of two types:

  1. Missense mutations: These involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases. It leads to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. These mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein. Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:
    • Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.
    • Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one.
  2. Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon.

For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

Option B: α-thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent synthesis of α-globin chains.

Option C: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation. It occurs due to the replacement of the 6th glutamic acid by valine in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11. 

Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with severe right upper quadrant pain for 8 hours associated with nausea and vomiting. A diagnosis of acute cholecystitis was made and he underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The specimen is shown below. This finding is associated with all the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows pigmented gallstones, which are not associated with hyperlipidemia syndromes.

Pigmented gallstones are made of bilirubin and calcium salts. They can occur in:

  • Chronic hemolytic syndromes
  • Ileal resection
  • Biliary infection
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

Cholesterol stones are made of crystalline cholesterol monohydrates. Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for the development of cholesterol gallstones.

The following image shows cholesterol gallstones:

questions.text: What is the normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio?
questions.solution:
The normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4 to 1:6. 

Normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio implies that the volume occupied by the cytoplasm is 4 to 6 times greater than the volume occupied by the nucleus.

Abnormal nuclear morphologies that are seen in malignant cells:

  • Nuclei disproportionately large for the cell
  • Nuclear shape is variable and often irregular
  • Chromatin 
    • Coarsely clumped 
    • Hyperchromatic
  • Nucleoli are abnormally large

questions.text: On which of the following chromosomes is the BRCA2 gene located?
questions.solution:
BRCA2 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q12.3). 

Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are responsible for 80 to 90% of single gene familial breast cancers and about 3% of all breast cancers.

ER-positive, HER2-negative cancers (luminal type) is the most common subtype of breast cancer in individuals who inherit germline mutations in BRCA2. This gene is associated more frequently with male breast cancer.

Single gene mutations associated with familial breast cancer can be categorized into:

  • High penetrance germline mutations (>4 fold increased risk) - BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, STK11, CDH I, PALPB2
  • Moderate penetrance germline mutations (2-4 fold increased risk) - ATM, CHEK2

Related Pearl: Comparison between BRCA 1 and BRCA 2:

Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes.

Carcinoma breast occurs at an earlier age and is bilateral and multicentric in inherited forms compared to sporadic cases.

  BRCA 1 BRCA 2
Location Long arm of chromosome 17  Long arm of chromosome 13
Differentiation Poorly differentiated Well-differentiated
Hormone receptor status ER/PR- Negative, Her-2 negative – triple negative ER/PR- Positive
Associated Cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, and prostate (lesser extent), Pancreas (lesser extent)  cancers Breast, ovarian, colon, prostate, pancreas, gall bladder, stomach cancers, and melanoma
Male breast carcinoma Low risk Increased risk
Fanconi’s anemia Not associated Associated
Medullary carcinoma Associated Not associated

questions.text: A patient presented with an abscess on his back. Septic precautions were taken and the abscess was drained. On follow up, a healthy scar was visible. What is the type of collagen seen in the provisional matrix in this type of healing?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of wound healing by secondary intention. The initial provisional matrix in this type of healing is composed of type III collagen, fibrin, and plasma fibronectin.

It is later replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen.

This type of healing occurs when cell or tissue loss is more extensive, such as in large wounds, abscesses, ulceration, and ischemic necrosis in parenchymal organs. The repair process involves a combination of regeneration and scarring.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs due to a defect in δ granules of the platelets?
questions.solution:
Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome occurs due to a defect in platelet δ granules.

Platelet granules disorders include: 

  • Gray platelet syndrome - involves α granules and characterized by thrombocytopenia with large platelets that appear pale on the peripheral smear (due to deficiency of the α granules)
  • Quebec platelet syndrome - defect in α granules 
  • Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome - defect in δ granules and characterized by hypopigmentation and bleeding manifestation
  • Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome - mutations in the WASp gene expressed in the X chromosome and characterized by microthrombocytopenia, eczema, recurrent infections

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings will be seen in patients with chronic alcoholism?
questions.solution:
Chicken-wire fence pattern of fibrosis is seen in the liver biopsy of patients with alcoholic steatohepatitis. This pattern is due to perisinusoidal fibrosis encircling small clusters of hepatocytes. 

Trichrome staining of liver biopsy specimen showing perisinusoidal fibrosis (stained blue) in characteristic chicken-wire fence pattern is given below.

Note: Other conditions with chicken-wire pattern in histopathology:

  • Chicken wire calcification - chondroblastoma
  • Chicken wire vasculature - oligodendroglioma and myxoid liposarcoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about CADASIL?

choices.text: It is characterized by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene.
Recurrent strokes and dementia are seen.

questions.solution:
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene. 

This leads to the misfolding of the extracellular domain of the NOTCH3 receptor that is preferentially expressed in vascular smooth muscle. It is clinically characterized by recurrent strokes (usually ischemic, less often hemorrhages) and dementia.

Arteries in the CNS and in other tissues such as skin show concentric thickening of the media and adventitia, loss of smooth muscle cells, and the presence of basophilic, periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive deposits. Deposits contain the misfolded NOTCH3 protein. These appear as osmiophilic compact granular material on electron microscopy and are consistently detected in the walls of affected vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following phases is impaired in patients diagnosed with Whipple's disease?
questions.solution:
In Whipple's disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport. 

In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic obstruction. These bacteria-laden macrophages also accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, synovial membranes of affected joints, cardiac valves, brain.

The clinical presentation of Whipple disease is usually a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had undergone modified radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy with trastuzumab. She now presents with liver metastases. Which of the following drugs could be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts a case of trastuzumab-refractory breast cancer and lapatinib is used in this condition.

Drug Use
Lapatinib Refractory and metastatic breast carcinoma
Panitumumab Colorectal carcinoma
Erlotinib
  • Non small cell lung carcinoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
Imatinib
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumour

In 2018, Dacomitinib has been approved by FDA for the treatment of metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer. It is a selective and irreversible inhibitor of EGFR.

questions.text: In the metabolism of xenobiotics, all of the following are phase 1 reactions except?
questions.solution:
Acetylation is a phase 2 reaction.

Metabolizing enzymes in hepatic cells:

  • Microsomal enzymes - present in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum
  • Non-microsomal enzymes - present in mitochondria and cytoplasm

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: Which group of antiarrhythmic drugs does dofetilide belong to?
questions.solution:
Class III drugs: MNEMONIC - BInDAS

B – Bretylium

In – Ibutilide

D – Dofetilide

A - Amiodarone

S – Sotalol (belongs to both class II and class III)

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. He admitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a brownish moiré pattern that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coli.

Bisacodyl is also implicated in causing melanosis coli.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about G-protein-coupled receptors?

choices.text: G proteins bind to hormones on the cell surface.
All the three subunits alpha, beta and gamma should bind to each other for G proteins to act.
G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit.
G protein is bound to GTP in resting state.

questions.solution:
G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit. 

  • Excitatory - Gs and Gq 
  • Inhibitory - Gi 

In the resting-state:

  • G protein is a heterotrimer consisting of alpha, beta, and gamma subunits. It forms a complex with G-protein-coupled receptors at the intracellular domain. The extracellular domain of GPCR has the binding domain for hormones. G protein subunits do not directly bind them. 
  • The alpha subunit is bound to GDP. 

The binding of ligand results in activation of GPCR, following which:

  • The alpha subunit undergoes a conformational change
  • Release of GDP and binding of GTP occurs
  • GTP-bound alpha subunit dissociates from beta-gamma subunit
  • Both the alpha subunit and beta-gamma subunit bind to and regulate effectors only when they are separated.

Other options: 

Option A: G proteins do not directly bind to hormones or signaling molecules. Hormones or ligands bind to the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), which is a transmembrane protein on the cell surface. The GPCR, once activated by the hormone, then interacts with the G protein to initiate signaling. 

Option B: In the resting state, the G protein exists as a trimer (alpha, beta, and gamma subunits bound together). However, for the G protein to act, it must dissociate into two parts: the alpha subunit and the beta-gamma dimer. This dissociation occurs when the G protein is activated (GTP replaces GDP on the alpha subunit). 

Option D: In the resting state, the G protein is bound to GDP (guanosine diphosphate), not GTP. When a ligand activates the GPCR, the receptor causes the G protein to exchange GDP for GTP. This exchange triggers the activation of the G protein, leading to the dissociation of the alpha subunit from the beta-gamma dimer. The G protein is considered active only when bound to GDP..

questions.text: Which of the following is the anticoagulant of choice in a patient, who  is undergoing  a surgery requiring cardiopulmonary bypass ?
questions.solution:
Heparin remains the agent of choice for surgery requiring cardiopulmonary bypass.

Other options : 

  • Fondaparinux is not used because of the risk of catheter thrombosis, a complication caused by catheter-induced activation of factor XII.
  • Lepirudin is used for treating thrombosis in  case of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
  • Dabigatran is used in treatment of acute venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A patient developed a surgical site infection with Klebsiella, which is found to be sensitive to a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. Which of the following antibiotics is this likely to be?
questions.solution:
Cefepime is an antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Aminoglycosides, doxycycline, and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors. 

Related Pearl: Cell wall synthesis inhibitors (mnemonic "BBC Van")

BBC Van:

  • Beta lactams
  • Bacitracin
  • Cycloserine
  • Vancomycin
  • Fosfomycin

questions.text: Therapeutic index is calculated with which of the following equations?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

Therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

LD50 (median lethal dose) refers to the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die. Larger the LD50, the safer the drug. In humans, TD50 is considered. TD50 refers to the dose of the drug that causes a toxic response in 50% of the population.

ED50 (median effective dose) refers to the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal necessary therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine receptor?
questions.solution:
The inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine receptor is beta-carboline.  

It impedes the action of GABA and can cause anxiogenic, convulsive, and memory-enhancing effects.

Option A: Barbiturates (phenobarbitone) are agonists at an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor that facilitate the action of GABA.

Option C: Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor.

Option D: Picrotoxin blocks Cl- channel non-competitively.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who was diagnosed with Sjogren's syndrome is on treatment with cevimeline. On which receptor does this drug mainly act for the expulsion of secretions from the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Cevimeline is an M3 receptor agonist resulting in the expulsion of the secretions from the salivary gland. This drug also enhances expulsion of lacrimal secretions in Sjögren’s syndrome.

Both M1 and M3 receptors are present in a salivary gland. Activation of M1 increases secretion and M3 causes smooth muscle contraction and expulsion of the secretions.

Receptors of Parasympathetic system Subtype Site
Nicotinic Nm Neuromuscular junction
Nn CNS, ganglia, Adrenal gland
Muscarinic M1 CNS, Ganglia, Salivary, and gastric glands
M2 Heart
M3 Smooth muscles, secretory glands, eyes - pupils, and blood vessels
M4 CNS
M5 CNS

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia risk is highest with the use of _______
questions.solution:
• Thrombocytopenia risk is highest with abciximab and occurs in around 5% of patients. Thrombocytopenia risk is around 1% for tirofiban and eptifibatide.
  • Thrombocytopenia mechanism:
    • Immune mediated
    • Binding of GpIIb/IIIa receptor antagonists
    • Exposure of neoantigens on platelet surface
    • Antibodies against these neoantigens cause thrombocytopenia

questions.text: Which of the following should be monitored if linezolid is given for more than 14 days?
questions.solution:
Linezolid use is associated with thrombocytopenia in >2% of patients. The occurrence is related to duration of treatment.

Platelet counts should be monitored in patients receiving linezolid beyond 2 weeks and in patients with risk of thrombocytopenia irrespective of the duration of treatment.

Note: Linezolid is associated with nephrotoxicity but the incidence is very rare. Linezolid and it's metabolites are not overt nephrotoxic agents that require regular RFT monitoring.

questions.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor approved for familial periodic paralysis
questions.solution:
Dichlorphenamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhbitor is approved for familial periodic paralysis. The mechanism for benefit is still unknown but most probable due to induction of metabolic acidosis. 

Chlorpheiramine is a first generation anti-histaminergic agent (Option A).

Diethylcarbamazine is an antifilarial agent (Option C).

Chloroprocaine is a local anesthetic (Option D).

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is started on flutamide therapy. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Flutamide acts by competitive inhibition of androgen receptors and is used to treat prostate cancer.

Flutamide is a non-steroidal antiandrogen that competes with androgens such as testosterone and dihydrotestosterone for binding to the androgen receptors in the prostate gland. By doing so, it prevents them from stimulating the prostate cancer cells to grow.

In addition to its use in prostate cancer, flutamide has been used to treat hyperandrogenism (excess androgen levels) in women, such as in those with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and Hirsutism.

Other anti-androgens are:

  • Bicalutamide, apalutamide, and nilutamide
  • Spironolactone  (aldosterone antagonist with antiandrogen activity)
  • Cyproterone acetate (progestin with antiandrogen activity)
  • Cimetidine (H2 blocker with anti-androgen activity)

Selective Androgen Receptor Modulators (SARMs) are a class of androgen receptor ligands that have similar anabolic properties to anabolic steroids, but with reduced androgenic side effects. There are no FDA-approved SARMs at present.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding exenatide?

choices.text: It can be used for the treatment of type 1 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
Exenatide is not indicated in type 1 diabetes mellitus.

Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog that acts as an insulin secretagogue. As the beta cells are already destroyed and do not secrete insulin in type 1 diabetes, there is no role of drugs that enhance insulin secretion.

Option A - Exenatide is a GLP-1 analog and it is synthesized from exendin-4 

Option C - It is a peptide and hence has to be administered subcutaneously 

Option D - It increases insulin secretion, decreases glucagon secretion, delays gastric emptying, and reduces food intake

questions.text: Which of the following drugs shows concentration-dependent killing?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing and are preferably dosed once daily for maximum effect.

Peak concentration above MIC (minimum inhibitory concentration) matters for certain classes of drugs for their antimicrobial action. It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. The period during which the concentration remains above MIC is not relevant for such drugs. Aminoglycosides and quinolones have this property.

Time-dependent killing: The antimicrobial action is dependent on the period for which the concentration of drug remains above the MIC. Penicillins, 5-fluorocytosine and vancomycin have this property.

questions.text: Amphotericin B is associated with normocytic, hypochromic anemia. The most probable reason for this adverse effect is
questions.solution:
Normocytic hypochromic anemia associated with amphotericin B is most likely due to decreased production of erythropoietin.

The anemia usually responds to administration of recombinant erythropoietin. 

Conventional formulation is more likely to cause anemia over lipid formulations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for follow-up. His wife states that recently he is forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the antitubercular drug that is implicated in the causation of transient memory loss.

Neurological toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and seizures can occur with isoniazid therapy. It is also associated with abnormalities like:

  • Euphoria
  • Transient memory loss
  • Separation of ideas and reality
  • Loss of self-control
  • Florid psychosis

Pyridoxine therapy can prevent and reverse most of the neurological toxicity and mental abnormalities.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action

Bactericidal

Blocks mycolic acid synthesis.

Bactericidal (maximum)

Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis.

Bactericidal

Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane.

Bacteriostatic

Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Location of Mycobacteria Intracellular +  Extracellular Intracellular +  Extracellular  Intracellular  Extracellular
Metabolism Liver  Liver (maximum)  Liver  Kidney
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: In which of the following patients is oxytocin not indicated?

choices.text: A primiparous woman with spontaneous premature labor
A multiparous woman with postpartum haemorrhage
A primiparous woman with uterine inertia
A patient with breast engorgement due to inefficient milk ejection reflex

questions.solution:
Spontaneous premature labor is not an indication for oxytocics. Infact, it is an indication for tocolytics.

Uses of oxytocin are:

  • Induction of labor
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Uterine inertia
  • Breast engorgement due to insufficient milk ejection reflex

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who is 10 weeks pregnant, comes with history of fever and chills. She is diagnosed with falciparum malaria. Which of the following drugs will you choose for her treatment?
questions.solution:
The woman is in the 1st trimester of pregnancy and falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy is treated with quinine plus clindamycin.

Worldwide, most species of Falciparum malaria are resistant to chloroquine. In all trimesters, pregnant women diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria caused by chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum infection can be treated with a combination of quinine and clindamycin.

Quinine is considered the drug of choice in the first trimester. In the second and third trimesters artemether-lumefantrine can be used, but not in the first trimester.

Vivax malaria during pregnancy is treated with chloroquine as chloroquine is safe in pregnancy and children.

Clindamycin can be used in children for chloroquine-resistant cases. It is safe to use in children and pregnant women.

Option B: Doxycycline is useful in the treatment of malaria but not used in pregnancy.

Options C and D: Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) is not recommended during the 1st trimester of pregnancy because of a lack of safety data.

questions.text: About 5 kg of tension in the ligature around the neck would occlude which of these following structures
questions.solution:
5kg of tension in the ligature would occlude Jugular vein and Carotid artery.

Structures affected by ligature around neck Tension in ligature
Jugular vein 2 Kg
Carotid artery 5 Kg
Trachea 15 Kg
Vertebral artery 20 Kg

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Amussat’s sign is an intimal tear of______
questions.solution:
• Amussat’s sign is an intimal tear of the carotid artery.
  • Important post-mortem findings of hanging:
    • Internal:
      • The fluidity of blood.
      • Tissues under ligature will be dry, pale and glistening.
      • There may be intimal tears of the carotid artery (Amussat’s sign).
      • Fracture of hyoid is seen in 15-20% of cases. Fracture of the thyroid cartilage and tracheal rings may be seen. There may be congestion and ecchymoses in trachea, epiglottis, esophagus, and larynx. All these injuries are more common in strangulation because strangulation is more violent than hanging causing more severe injury to neck structures.

questions.text: A pregnant woman suffered a miscarriage at 6 months of gestation. What would be the expected crown heel length of this fetus?
questions.solution:
Crown heel length of a 6-month-old fetus would be 30 cm.

According to the rule of Hasse:

  • During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months.
  • During last five months, the length in centimeters is divided by five gives the age in months.

So, crown heel length = age in months × 5 (i.e. 6 × 5 = 30 cm).

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to the ER with severe dehydration and weakness. History was suggestive of multiple episodes of watery diarrhea and non-bilious vomiting since morning. His breath reeked of garlic odor. ECG showed QT prolongation.  Which of the following samples must be collected for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of acute arsenic poisoning. For a definitive diagnosis, the arsenic levels are measured in 24-hour urine samples.

If the baseline urinary level is within normal limits and arsenic intoxication is still suspected, hair and nail clippings should be harvested for laboratory analysis. Due to the rapid distribution of arsenic in tissues, blood arsenic levels are unreliable.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: Sexual asphyxia is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Sexual asphyxia (autoerotic asphyxia/asphyxiophilia) is seen in masochism and transvestism. 

Pressure on carotid vessels/partial airway obstruction leads to cerebral hypoxia and impaired consciousness. This causes erotic hallucinations and sexual pleasure. A controlled degree of mechanical asphyxia is produced, but accidental deaths can happen.

Option A: Lust murder is an extreme case of sadism where murder serves as a stimulus for a sexual act. Death is not accidental, as is in the case of sexual asphyxia. 

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of the mouth to the sexual organs. 

Option D: Frotteurism is a perversion mostly seen in males, where they obtain sexual gratification from rubbing their genitalia on unsuspecting females.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a false positive hydrostatic test in fetus seen?
questions.solution:
The hydrostatic test is falsely positive in the case of putrefied fetus.

Hydrostatic test is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not. It is also known as floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test.

If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth. If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, which means it is stillborn.

An unrespired lung (stillbirth) may float, giving a false positive test, due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction. 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest tooth to erupt in a 7-month-old baby?
questions.solution:
The earliest tooth to erupt in a 7-month-old baby (primary dentition) is a mandibular central incisor.

The time of emergence of primary dentition or temporary teeth:

Tooth Emergence
Mandibular central incisor 6-8 months
Maxillary central incisor 7-9 months
Maxillary lateral incisor 7-9 months
Mandibular lateral incisor 10-12 months
First molar 12-14 months
Canine 17-18 months
Second molar 20-30 months

The deciduous teeth all emerge into the mouth by 2.5-3 years.

The time of emergence of secondary dentition or permanent teeth:

Tooth Emergence
First molar 6-7 years
Central incisors 6-8 years
Lateral incisors 7-9 years
First premolar 9-11 years
Second premolar 10-12 years
Canine 11-12 years
Second molar 12-14 years
Third molar 18-25 years

Note: 6-13 years is the age of mixed dentition. First molar emerges at 6-7 years. Second molar emerges at 12 years and third molar emerges beyond 18 years of age.

questions.text: What does BNS section 90/IPC Section 314 deal with?

choices.text: Death of mother due to miscarriage
Preventing the child being born alive

questions.solution:
BNS Section 90/IPC Section 314 deals with the death of the mother due to miscarriage.

Important sections of IPC relating to miscarriages:

BNS section

IPC section

Deals with

88

312

Causing miscarriage with consent

89

313

Causing miscarriage without consent

90

314

Death of mother due to miscarriage

91

315

Preventing the child from being born alive or causing it to die after birth

92

316

Causing the death of the quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide

Note: Quick child is a fetus that has developed to such a stage that it moves within the womb of the mother. It shall mean an unborn child whose heart is beating, who is experiencing electronically measurable brain waves, who is discernibly moving, and who is so far developed and matured as to be capable of surviving the trauma of birth with the aid of usual medical care and facilities available in this state.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining the pelvic bone and lower vertebrae of an unknown individual, to determine the sex. Which of the following is regarded as the best source of information for the same?
questions.solution:
The greater sciatic notch, which is a part of the ilium is the ideal feature to determine sex.

The sacrum is the least reliable bone for sex determination.

The femur is the most useful long bone for sex determination, due to its length and massiveness.

Pearson and Bell's criteria for sexing of the femur are:

  • Vertical diameter of the femoral head - most useful criterion
  • Popliteal length
  • Bicondylar width
  • Oblique trochanteric length

questions.text: Rinne positive in both ears and Weber lateralised towards left indicates
questions.solution:
It is Right sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Since Weber is lateralised towards left, it indicates left sided conductive deafness or right sided sensorineural deafness.

Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following arteries does not contribute to its formation?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area (anteroinferior part of the septum).

The contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery, which supplies nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

This question was asked in recent AIIMS and NEET examinations, making it a potential repeat.

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm).

The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter  and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

Related Pearl: Parts of Intratemporal Division of Facial Nerve

Segment Within From To Length (mm) Remarks
Meatal Internal Acoustic Meatus Porus acousticus (medial end of IAM) Fundus (lateral end of IAM) 8-10 Only intra-temporal segment that is not within fallopian canal
Labyrinthine Fallopian canal Fundus 1st genu/ geniculate ganglion 3-5 Shortest and the narrowest
Tympanic/ Horizontal Fallopian canal 1st genu 2nd genu 11 Runs on medial wall of middle ear
Mastoid/ Vertical Fallopian canal 2nd genu Stylomastoid foramen 13 Runs in posterior wall of middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following muscles form the Passavant’s ridge?
questions.solution:
Passavant’s ridge is a mucosal ridge raised by the fibers of the palatopharyngeus. 

It encircles the posterior and lateral walls of nasopharyngeal isthmus. Soft palate, during its contraction makes firm contact with the ridge to cut off nasopharynx from the oropharynx during deglutition or speech.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

ASOM: Acute suppurative otitis media; CSOM: Chronic suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. The swelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is a gurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.

Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition.

Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years.

Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.

questions.text: Which of the following deformity is likely to be seen in a patient with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma when spreads to the orbit, lead to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog-face deformity.

Option A: Gorilla-like facies are seen in acromegaly.

Option C: Bird-like facies are seen in the Pierre-Robin sequence.

Option D: Lion-like facies are seen in Paget's disease of bone when craniofacial bones are involved.

questions.text: A patient with deviated nasal septum presents with a headache that starts upon waking and reaches its peak by about midday. On examination, she has upper eyelid oedema and tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus. Which of the following X-ray views is preferred to best evaluate the sinus involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of frontal sinusitis. The best view for evaluating the frontal sinus is Caldwell's view.

It is also known as occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: What is the transformer ratio of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The transformer ratio of the middle ear is 22:1

The middle ear has to conduct sound waves from a low impedance tympanic membrane to a high impedance oval window. This is done by matching their impedances. It is called transforming action.

Transformer ratio =Areal ratio × Lever ratio

questions.text: How frequently does the rhythmic congestion and decongestion of nasal mucosa occur?
questions.solution: Rhythmic cyclical congestion and decongestion of the nasal mucosa is called nasal cycle. It occurs every 2.5-4 hours and is usually characteristic of an individual.

questions.text: True statement about Ocular tumors is all except?

choices.text: Metastasis is most common intra-ocular malignancy of adults
Retinoblastoma is most common intra-ocular malignancy of children
Sebaceous cell carcinoma is more common  in upper eyelid
Most common primary intra-ocular malignancy of Adults -Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.solution:
Most common primary intra-ocular malignancy of Adults –Uveal melanoma

Ocular tumor most common list (mc)

  • MC cause of eyelid tumor - Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • MC manifestation of RB - leukocoria
  • MC malignant orbital tumor in children - Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • MC orbital benign tumor in adults - Cavernous hemangioma
  • MC cause of Eye lid malignancy – Basal cell carcinoma (usually appears in the lower lid)
  • Sebaceous carcinoma is the second most common eyelid cancer.( usually appears in the Upper lid)
  • MC orbital tumor causing proptosis - Hemangioma
  • MC primary intraocular tumor in adults - Uveal melanoma
  • MC primary intra ocular tumour in children - Retinoblastoma
  • MC intraocular tumor in adults (overall) - metastasis
  • MC cause of metastasis in Choroid in males - Lung cancer
  • MC cause of metastasis in choroid in females - breast cancer
  • MC site of Metastasis of uveal melanoma - Liver
  • MC site of BCC eyelid - Lower lid

questions.text: Identify the stage of senile cataract depicted in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the characteristic appearance of Morgagnian hypermature cataract.

Morgagnian hypermature cataract is characterized by the liquefaction of the entire cortex. The lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid. The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, its position altering with a change in the position of the head.

Senile Cataract

Types:

  • Cortical (soft cataract): 75%   
  • Nuclear (hard cataract): 25%

Cortical cataract is further divided into the cuneiform and cupuliform types.

Cuneiform (70%) Posterior subcapsular/Cupuliform (5%)

Radial spoke-like opacity starting in the periphery and extending centrally

Central saucer-shaped opacity in the posterior cortex just below the capsule

Late visual loss

Early loss of visual acuity
 

Most visually handicapping senile cataract 

 

Nuclear cataract

  • Pigmented nuclear cataracts: Due to the deposition of urochrome pigment
    • Catarata brunescens
    • Catarata nigra
    • Catarata rubra

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl with high myopia was referred by the optometrist for further evaluation. She has a history of recurrent allergic conjunctivitis and persistent eye rubbing. An image is given below. Which of the following statements are true about the given condition?
  1. It is usually associated with regular astigmatism
  2. Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool
  3. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice
  4. Vogt's striae and Rizzuti sign are both findings 
  5. The area of protrusion is mostly inferotemporal
questions.solution:
Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder.  It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

The pathogenesis is not fully known. Several associations have been identified, which include rigid contact lens wear, chronic eye rubbing, Down's syndrome, atopic disease, Leber's congenital amaurosis, and connective tissue disease.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often causes significant myopia and irregular astigmatism. 

Corneal topography is the primary diagnostic tool for KCN detection. 

Whereas keratoplasty, historically has been the mainstay of treatment for keratoconus, it is now generally reserved for eyes that are unable to achieve functional vision with other surgical or non-surgical modalities and is only considered only as a last resort, in very advanced disease. It is the definitive treatment for keratoconus, not the treatment of choice.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

questions.text: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children. 

Conjunctival appearance:

1. In trachoma

  • Sago-grain appearance
  • A follicular reaction 

2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis

  • Cobblestone appearance
  • A papillary reaction seen in palpebral conjunctiva

3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

  • White-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva

4. Xerophthalmia

  • Epithelial xerosis
  • Bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva

On December 08, 2017, Shri J P Nadda, Union Minister of Health and Family Welfare at that time, released the National Trachoma Survey Report and declared that India is now free from 'infective trachoma'.

questions.text: A young patient with visual disturbances was found to have a brain tumour. He was referred to ophthalmology for a complete visual field assessment before planning his resection. Humprey analyzer revealed the following plot. What is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect shown is the typical "pie in the sky" defect or superior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer's loop) are involved.

"Pie in the floor" defects refer to inferior quadrantic hemianopia. It is seen in the involvement of the superior fibers of optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop).

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
questions.solution:
Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema.

Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure (ICP).

"Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicate a disc swollen from other causes.

All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass.

Features of papilledema:

  • Raised ICP
  • Edema of the optic nerve head
    • Blockage of axoplasmic flow
    • Axonal swelling
    • Collection of extracellular fluid
  • Painless progressive loss of vision
  • Enlargement of the blind spot
  • Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.

questions.text: A patient with a history of uncomplicated cataract surgery 1 year back, presents with pain, redness, and purulent discharge from his right eye. A greyish-white serpiginous ulcer was noted over the lower third of the cornea. The anterior chamber showed a 4 mm hypopyon and a moderate flare reaction. A smear from the ulcerated area is likely to demonstrate which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Hypopyon corneal ulcer with a characteristic serpiginous description (ulcus serpens) is typically caused by Pneumococcus. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. 

Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the centre of the cornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion.

Risk factors include both surgical and non-surgical ocular trauma, dry eye, chronic corneal disease, immune alterations and contact lenses.

An examination may reveal the following signs:

  • Swelling of lids and blepharospasm
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Ciliary congestion, hypopyon and anterior chamber flare reaction
  • Iridocyclitis 

Image given below shows ulcus serpens.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text:
Match the findings of the given patients (i, ii, iii, iv) with the appropriate category of blindness they fall under.

i. Unable to count fingers at 6m 

ii. Vision 1/60 to the perception of light

iii. Best-corrected visual acuity less than 3/60

iv. No perception of light 

 

A. Absolute blindness

B. Economic blindness 

C. Manifest blindness 

D. Social blindness
questions.solution:
Type of Blindness Description
Social Blindness Presenting distance visual acuity of less than 3/60 (20/400) in the better eye and limitation of the field of vision to be less than 10 degrees from the center of fixation
Economic blindness The inability of a person to count fingers from a distance of 6 meters
Manifest blindness Vision 1/60 to just perception of light
Absolute blindness No perception of light
Curable blindness That stage of blindness where the damage is reversible by prompt management, e.g., cataract
Preventable blindness Loss of vision that could have been completely prevented by the institution of effective preventive or prophylactic measures e.g.,  xerophthalmia, trachoma, and glaucoma 
Avoidable blindness The sum total of preventable and curable blindness is often referred to as avoidable blindness.

questions.text: A 25-year-old artist visits an art gallery. A painting of checkered squares appears distorted only to him, as shown below. He decides to go see an ophthalmologist who after initial evaluation, suggests an FFA. The FFA  shows a characteristic smoke stack appearance. Breakdown of which of the following barriers is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a characteristic smoke stack pattern on FFA is suggestive of a diagnosis of central serous retinopathy. In CSR, the outer blood-retinal barrier is disrupted.

CSR is the serous detachment of the neurosensory retina with focal and multifocal areas of leakage at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), mainly affecting the macular area. That is why the patient who is usually a young male presents with macular symptoms such as blurring of central vision, metamorphopsia.

The blood-retina barrier (BRB) is composed of inner and outer barriers. The outer BRB refers to the barrier formed at the retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cell layer and regulates the movement of solutes and nutrients from the choroid to the sub-retinal space. By contrast, the inner BRB, similar to the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is located in the inner retinal microvasculature and comprises the microvascular endothelium, which lines these vessels.

The image given below shows the smoke-stack pattern seen in CSR.

Amsler grid is used in detecting maculopathy.

Uses:

  • Assess macular function
  • Evaluate the visual field of 10°
  • Good for follow-up in CSR

The image below shows Amsler's grid.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist evaluating a patient with glaucoma identifies the following finding on slit-lamp examination. What is the finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pattern of the deposition of pigments on the back of the cornea in pigmentary glaucoma. They are called Krukenberg spindles. 

Pigmentary glaucoma is an open-angle glaucoma having the following features:

  • Krukenberg spindles
  • Gonioscopy shows pigment accumulation along the Schwalbe line inferiorly, and this accumulation is called the Sampaolesi line.
  • Radial transillumination defect in the iris is a pathognomonic feature.
  • Pigment granules may be deposited on the anterior surface. There may be a Scheie line or Zentmayer ring of pigment on the peripheral/equatorial surface around the zonular insertions.

Other options:

Option A: Ferry line: Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs of glaucoma surgery

Option B: Fleischer line/ring: Epithelial iron deposits at the base of the cone in keratoconus

Option C: Hudson–Stahli line: Iron deposition line in the corneal epithelium, which is commonly seen in the junction between middle and lower third cornea. This finding is mainly age-related.

questions.text: Which of the following concepts in the hypothesis testing is incorrect?

choices.text: Alpha is the maximum tolerable probability of a type 1 error being made
Beta is the probability of a type II error
When the null hypothesis is true but rejected, it is a type II error
P value can be more or less than alpha

questions.solution:
When the null hypothesis is true but is yet rejected, it is a type I error.

Type II errors are when an alternative hypothesis is rejected even though it is true.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: Free and combined chlorines in water are separately identified by:
questions.solution:
• Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both combined and free chlorines in water separately.
  • Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorines together.
  • Chloronomes are devices used to regulate dose of chlorine gas used for disinfection.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people out of which 15 have a disease. The test showed 22 people tested positive for the disease among which 14 actually had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of the above screening test is 93%.

The given data is represented below

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14(TP)

8(FP)

22

Test -

1(FN)

91(TN)

92

Total

15(TP+FN)

99(FP+TN)

114

TP- true positive, FP- false positive, FN- false negative, TN- true negative

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 14/15 = 93%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: The period between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible point of detection and the usual time of diagnosis is called lead time.

Lead time refers to the benefit obtained through screening and refers to the time frame between the initial detection of a condition through early diagnosis compared to diagnosis through alternative methods.

Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection in a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: Which of the following does the Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refer to?

choices.text: Initiative for providing free sanitary pads
Initiative to provide vaccination to under-5 children
Initiative for labour room quality improvement
Initiative to provide affordable healthcare to all

questions.solution:
The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the Government of India refers to the initiative for labour room quality improvement.

There is enough evidence to support the fact that improving the quality of care in labour rooms, especially on the day of birth, is crucial to maternal and neonatal survival.

Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care being provided to the pregnant mother in the labour room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth. This initiative is implemented in government medical colleges besides district hospitals, and high delivery load sub-district hospitals, and community health centres.

It plans to conduct quality certification of labour rooms and also incentivize facilities achieving the targets outlined. The goal is to reduce preventable maternal and new-born mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in labour room and maternity OT, and ensure respectful maternity care.

questions.text: A group of cardiologists found a correlation coefficient of 0.90  (p-value = 0.01) between the systolic BP and serum cholesterol levels of patients attending their clinics. Which of the following statements is an incorrect interpretation of this study?

choices.text: The magnitude of systolic BP and serum cholesterol levels are closely related
A patient with a high systolic BP is likely to have high serum cholesterol
A patient with a low systolic BP is likely to have low serum cholesterol
80% of the variation in BP can be explained by serum cholesterol and vice versa

questions.solution:
Correlation is an indicator of the strength and direction of the relationship between 2 variables, not the magnitude.

The given study is statistically significant (p-value = 0.01) with a strong positive correlation (r = +0.90) between systolic BP and cholesterol levels. Thus, it is likely that patients with high systolic BP will have high cholesterol levels and those with low BP will have low cholesterol levels.

The coefficient of determination (r2)here is 0.9 x 0.9 = 0.81. This indicates that around 80% of the variation in systolic BP among the patients can be explained by serum cholesterol levels.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true about POSHAN Abhiyan?

choices.text: It is a programme of the Ministry of Women and Child Development
The goals are to achieve improvement in neonatal mortality
Launched on the date of International Women's Day 2018
Targets to reduce low birth weight by 2% per annum

questions.solution:
The goal of POSHAN Abhiyaan /National Nutrition Mission (NNM) is to achieve an improvement in the nutritional status during the next three years beginning 2017-18. It is a flagship programme of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD). Its target population include:

  • children from 0-6 years
  • adolescent girls
  • pregnant women
  • lactating mothers 

The logo is:

The following image depicts the targets of this mission:

Note: Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government scheme in India to provide Rs.500 per month for TB patients to buy food.

 

The National Nutrition Week is an annual event, observed from 1 to 7 September every year initiated by the Food and Nutrition Board. The main objective is to raise awareness on the importance of nutrition for health which has an impact on development, productivity, economic growth, and ultimately national development.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic:
questions.solution:
The image given represents propagated epidemic which results from "person to person transmission".
