Single exposure / Point source epidemic Common source / Continuous epidemic Propagated epidemic
A sharp rise and sharp fall in the number of cases Sharp rise in the number of cases Gradual rise and gradual fall over a long time
Clustering of cases in a narrow interval of time such that all cases develop within one incubation period of the disease A fall in the number of cases is interrupted by "secondary waves/peaks" Results from "person-to-person transmission"

Eg: Food poisoning, Measles, Chickenpox, Cholera, Bhopal Gas tragedy

 Eg: Contaminated well in a village, Prostitute in a gonorrhoea outbreak, Legionnaire's disease outbreak in Philadelphia Eg: HIV, TB 

The below image depicts the various epidemic curves.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding "Intensified Mission Indradhanush" ?

choices.text: It is for urban slums with migratory population
It includes vaccination against 12 vaccine preventable diseases
It ensures full immunization to more than 90% by December 2018
It reaches to children under 5 years of age

questions.solution:
Intensified Mission Indradhanush(IMI) aims to reach each and every child under two years of age and all those pregnant women who have been left uncovered under the routine immunisation programme.

12 vaccines of Mission indradhanush:

  • Seven vaccines were included in it previously (Diphtheria, Whooping cough, Tetanus, Poliomyelitis, Tuberculosis, Measles, and Hepatitis B. Hemophilus influenza is given in some states)
  • In 2016 four new vaccines were added (Japanese B Encephalitis, Rubella, Rotavirus, Injectable polio vaccine).
  • In 2017 pneumonia was added to the mission by incorporating pneumococcal conjugate vaccine into the universal immunization programme.

The special drive will focus on improving immunization coverage in select districts and cities to ensure full immunization to more than 90% by December 2018. The achievement of full immunization under Mission Indradhanush to at least 90% coverage was to be achieved by 2020 earlier. With the launch of IMI, the achievement of the target has now been advanced. 

 

IMI is for:

  • Urban slums with a migratory population
  • Nomadic sites
  • Areas with low immunization coverage identified through measles outbreak, cases of diphtheria and neonatal tetanus in the last 2 years.

Remember Intensified Mission Indradhanush:7 working days in a month, starting on 7th of every month, excluding Sundays, holidays and immunization days.

questions.text: A new genetic syndrome has been defined and its etiology is being debated by many scholars all around the world. Which of the following would be the study of choice for formulating an aetiological hypothesis of this syndrome?
questions.solution:
A descriptive study is the study of choice for formulating an aetiological hypothesis of disease.

Descriptive study:

Descriptive studies are limited to the description of a disease including its etiology, pathogenesis, and occurrence, in a population.

Procedures in descriptive studies

  • Defining the population to be studied
  • Defining the disease under study
  • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
  • Measurement of disease
  • Comparing with known indices
  • Formulation of an aetiological hypothesis

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Perflation is not a type of mechanical ventilation. It is a type of natural ventilation.

Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical:

Natural ventilation includes:

  • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
  • Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action.
  • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings.
  • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other.

The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible.

Mechanical ventilation includes:

  • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
  • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
  • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
  • Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.

questions.text: Which of these terms is used for paired t tests?
questions.solution:
Paired t tests are also called correlated pairs t test, paired samples t test, or dependent samples t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct relationship between variance and standard deviation?

choices.text: Variance = square root of standard deviation
Standard deviation = square root of variance

questions.solution:
Standard deviation is the square root of variance.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: An epidemiologist determines to evaluate the strength of association between asbestos exposure and mesothelioma in a case-control study. Which of the following variables would he use for it?
questions.solution:
Odds ratio (OR), also known as cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of association between risk factor (asbestos exposure) and outcome (mesothelioma) in case-control studies.

A case-control study yields only odds ratio and not incidence or relative risk.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator. 

A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators.

Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.  

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: Spread of disease via which of the following is an example of an indirect mode of transmission?
questions.solution:
The spread of a disease through contaminated food is an example of vehicle-borne transmission. It is an indirect mode of transmission.

Vehicle-borne transmission is the transmission of infectious agents through food, water and biological products (blood, plasma etc.). Of these, food and water are more frequent vehicles of transmission because they are used by everyone.

Mother to child transmission, droplet infection and transmission via dog bite are examples of direct modes of transmission.

Related Pearl: Modes of Transmission of Communicable Diseases

Direct

Indirect

Direct contact

Droplet infection

Contact with soil

Inoculation into skin or mucosa

Vertical (transplacental)

Vehicle-borne

Vector borne – mechanical or biological

Air borne – droplet nuclei or dust

Fomite borne

Unclean hands and finger

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pathogenic mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Aedes and Anopheles lay eggs singly.

Culex lays eggs in rafts and Mansonia lays eggs in star-shaped clusters.

Anopheles has spotted wings while the other pathogenic species have unspotted wings.

Aedes transmits yellow fever, dengue and chikungunya. Culex is the main vector for JE and filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle is India in currently?
questions.solution:
Currently, India is in stage 3 i.e. late expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

Note: The year 1921 is called the year of the great divide in India. This is because, since 1921, the absolute number of people getting added to the population during each decade has been on the rise. This is the year in which India moved from stage 2 to stage 3 of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage?
questions.solution:
In triage, green signifies low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

An internationally accepted four-color coded system, with red having the highest priority is used commonly here.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: In individuals exposed to HIV, within how many hours should prophylaxis be initiated?
questions.solution: Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should ideally be initiated within 72 hours. It is recommended that it be started as even as early as < 2 hours.

questions.text: While investigating a new disease, you are trying to establish the aetiological agent. Which of the following criterion is the most difficult to establish?
questions.solution:
Specificity is the most difficult criterion to establish in both chronic and acute diseases.

This is because a single factor or cause can give rise to more than one disease. Also, most diseases are multifactorial in origin with no possibility of demonstrating a one-to-one relationship which would indicate specificity.

Related Pearl: Hill's Criteria for Causal Association

  • It is also called Bradford Hill criteria.
  • It was established in 1965 by English epidemiologist, Sir Austin Bradford Hill.

Criteria

Brief Description

Temporality

Suspected cause precedes observed effect.

Strength

Larger the relative risk, the more likely it is causal.

Consistency

If the association is observed repeatedly under the same or various conditions, then more likely it is causation.

Specificity

When exposure is associated with a specific outcome only, then it is more likely to be causal.

Plausibility

A biologically plausible mechanism between cause and effect can be support for causation.

Coherence

A causal conclusion should not seriously conflict with the present substantive knowledge of the outcome.

Analogy

Other established cause-effect relationships may be used in analogies to support this causal relationship.

Gradient

It is called dose-response or response curve. It refers to the existence of an exposure-response relationship.

Experiment

To check if the condition can be or has been changed, weakened or prevented by experimental approach.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about herd immunity?

choices.text: It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals
Vaccination allows the possibility of 100% herd immunity against a disease
It is affected by presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts
It doesn’t protect the individual in the case of tetanus

questions.solution:
It is not possible to achieve 100% herd immunity against a certain disease but studies have shown this is not necessary for disease control.

Herd structure is never constant. It is subject to constant variation because of new births, deaths and population mobility. An ongoing immunization programme will keep up the herd immunity at a very high level.

Related Pearl: Herd Immunity

  • Herd immunity is the level of protection of a community against a particular disease brought about by vaccination or immunization.
  • It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized individuals.
  • It is difficult to maintain the chain of infection if a large portion of the population is immune to a certain disease.
  • Elements which contribute to herd immunity are:
    • Occurrence of clinical and sub-clinical infection in the herd
    • Immunization of the herd
    • Herd structure
  • The herd structure not only includes the primary species but also the presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts, vectors and other environmental/social factors that are related to disease spread.
  • It is not possible or necessary to achieve 100% herd immunity in a population.
  • The proportion of immune individuals above which a disease may no longer spread is called herd immunity threshold.
  • This threshold depends upon the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the population.
  • Herd immunity is determined by serological surveys.
  • Herd immunity doesn’t offer protection against diseases like tetanus.

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for infertility. She gives a history of being employed in the printing industry. Exposure to which of the following is likely to cause this situation?
questions.solution:
A woman working in the printing industry is likely to suffer from infertility due to lead toxicity. 

More industrial workers are exposed to lead than to any other toxic metal. Occupational exposure to lead is seen in several industries including the manufacturing of storage batteries, glass, shipbuilding, printing, potteries, and rubber industries. 

The effects of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, blue-line on the gums (Burton's line), stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist & foot drop, headache, and convulsions. In young or pregnant women, prolonged lead exposure can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, premature birth, and low birth weight.

The World Day for Safety and Health at Work conducted on April 28 every year promotes the prevention of occupational accidents and diseases globally.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: Which of the following indices of obesity is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in metres?
questions.solution:
Quetelet's index (Body Mass Index) is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in metres.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

Body weight: +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:

  • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
  • Ponderal index: Weight (kg)/Height^3 (m)
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)

Broca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 

Lorentz's formula 
Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]

Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.

Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.

Total body water

Total body potassium

Body density 

Related Pearl: Body mass index

Recent update for Asian population:

Classification Global population (kg/m2)  

Indian population

(kg/m2)
Underweight <18.5

<18.5
Normal  18.5-24.99 18.5-22.99
Overweight 25-29.99 23-24.99 (and At risk)
Obesity >30 >25
Class I obesity 30.0-34.9  25- 29.9
Class II Obesity 35.0 to 39.9  >30
Class III Obesity (severe, extreme, massive) ≥40  

Note:

Lethal BMI:

BMI Value of 13 is considered as “Lethal” in men.

Females withstand and survive even at lower BMI rate upto 11.

questions.text: All the following are true about ESI Act except

choices.text: The state government provides 1/8th of the medical benefit expenses
Medical benefit is given in the form of no cash benefit

questions.solution:
Employee contributes 0.75% of the wage

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding EEG frequencies?
questions.solution:
EEG Wave Frequencies:

Alpha waves 8 - <13 Hz
Beta waves 13 – 30 Hz
Theta waves  4 – 8 Hz
Delta waves <4 Hz

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of cerebral edema?
questions.solution:
Hypernatermia does not cause cerebral edema but hyponatremia causes it.

Acute cerebral edema is generally seen in hyponatremia due to the following mechanism:

Acute hyponatremia->Increased interstitial pressure -> Shunting of extracellular fluid (ECF) and solutes from interstitial space to CSF and then systemic circulation-> Efflux of Na+, K+, and Cl- from brain cells -> Rapid decrease in tonicity overwhelms regulatory mechanisms -> Acute hyponatremic encephalopathy -> Acute cerebral edema.

  • Lead and Cerebral Edema: Toxic effects of systemic lead exposure manifest in the CNS generally as acute encephalopathy in children and polyneuropathy in adults. Cerebral edema, especially of the white matter is most commonly seen in children with lead intoxication.
  • Liver Failure and Cerebral Edema: Acute liver failure commonly causes brain edema, seizures, and agitation. Brain edema has been linked to persistent hyperammonemia in acute liver failure. Brain edema is one of the leading causes of mortality in acute liver failure.
  • High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE): HACE is a condition in the spectrum of altitude-related neurologic disorders that occurs in rapid ascent. It is an encephalopathy that rapidly causes ataxia and altered consciousness with diffuse cerebral involvement but without focal neurological deficits.

questions.text: True about CURB-65 criteria to assess pneumonia severity is
questions.solution:
The CURB-65 criteria is used to assess the severity of pneumonia.

It includes five variables:

  • Confusion
  • Urea >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg
  • Age ≥65 years

questions.text: Which of the following is not a diagnostic criterion for irritable bowel syndrome?

choices.text: Persistent diarrhoea after a 48 hour fast

questions.solution:
Persistent diarrhoea after a 48-hour fast is not a diagnostic criteria for IBS.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: The treatment for acute hepatitis C is
questions.solution:
Ribavirin and Pegylated IFN are used in acute hepatitis C infection.

  • Ribavarin and Pegylated interferon would be the best option.
  • Ribavirin is added if HCV RNA failed to clear after 3 months of peginterferon, but some authorities recommended using ribavirin with peginterferon from the start of therapy.
  • Treatment during the acute infection period consists of monitoring HCV RNA for at least 12 weeks to 16 weeks before starting treatment is recommended to allow for spontaneous clearance.

Note: If the options include newer regimens such as directly acting antivirals (DAA), then it would be a better option. Besides, consider the time frame if mentioned in question.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in patients with brain stem injury?
questions.solution:
Patients with brain stem injury develop type 2 respiratory failure. It is characterized by low pO2 and high pCO2.

Acute respiratory failure refers to acute impairment in gas exchange between the lungs and the blood causing hypoxia with or without hypercapnia.

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings are unlikely to be present in a patient with hyperkalemia?
questions.solution: Prolonged QT interval is not a feature of hyperkalemia, it is a feature of hypokalemia.

questions.text: The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis is:

choices.text: Normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
Normal anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis
High anion gap hypochloremic metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The type of acidosis seen in renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is normal anion gap hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. 

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which acidosis occurs because of the inability of the tubules of the kidney to perform normal functions required to maintain acid-base balance. In this disorder, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is relatively well-preserved.

The defect is either inability to excrete hydrogen ions (inadequate generation of new bicarbonate ions) or inadequate reabsorption of bicarbonate ions. 

Types of RTA:

  • Type I - distal RTA or classical RTA is characterised by the inability to excrete H+ ions by the distal nephron. The urinary pH is >5.5, as the urine cannot be fully acidified, despite systemic acidosis. 
  • Type II - proximal RTA is characterised by the inability to reabsorb filtered bicarbonate by the proximal tubule.
  • Type III - mixed type, similar to both type I and II.
  • Type IV - is the most common type of RTA in clinical practice. This is a disorder of hyperkalemia, that occurs due to decreased aldosterone, which inhibits ammonium production.

The anion gap is the difference between readily measured anions and cations. The normal anion gap is 12 ± 4 mEq/L. The overall deficiency of HCO3- in all the types of RTA is compensated by Cl- secretion. Hence, the serum anion gap remains normal. This kind of metabolic abnormality is also seen in gastrointestinal losses.

questions.text:
The flow-volume loop given below in purple most likely denotes?
(Considering Blue flow volume loop denotes the normal)
questions.solution: The given flow volume loop is indicative of fixed upper airway obstruction like tracheal stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding multiple sclerosis?

choices.text: It is an acute inflammatory condition of neurons
It is an autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system
It may also involve the peripheral nervous system
The condition is always benign and resolves spontaneously

questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system. It is characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss.

The peripheral nervous system is spared in MS.

The course of the disease may be relapsing-remitting or progressive. The clinical course of manifestation can be variable ranging from a benign condition to a rapidly evolving and incapacitating disease.

questions.text: While examining a chronic alcoholic patient, you notice the given finding. Which of the following is false regarding it?

choices.text: Occurs due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen
Presence of even 1 lesion is abnormal
Commonly seen over the superior vena cava territory
Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after release

questions.solution:
The given image shows spider telangiectasia and the presence of >2 to 3 of these are considered abnormal.

Spider telangiectasias are dilated arterioles with a prominent central arteriole with radiating vessels appearing in the shape of a spider. They are generally seen in the superior vena cava territory. Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after the release of pressure. They occur due to a hyperestrogenic state which is caused by defective estrogen metabolism in liver cirrhosis.

Clinical features seen in cirrhosis include:

  • Spider telangiectasias
  • Palmar erythema
  • Terry's nails - pallor of the proximal nail bed
  • Clubbing
  • Gynaecomastia
  • Caput medusae - dilated abdominal veins.
  • Parotid enlargement

The image below shows Terry's nails.

questions.text: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP.

It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. 

Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae.

Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance.

Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral bodies.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: Which hormone is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome. The hormones are affected in the order of GH → Prolactin → LH and FSH → ACTH → TSH

Sheehan syndrome refers to postpartum pituitary necrosis following severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). During pregnancy, the pituitary gland undergoes hypertrophy with increased blood supply. This makes it susceptible to ischemia and infarction when there is severe hypovolemia.

The clinical presentation depends on the amount of damage to the pituitary.

  • Mild - can go unnoticed for many years
  • Moderate - develops over months
    • Lactation failure
    • Failure to resume menses
    • Mild fatigue and anorexia
  • Severe - endocrine emergency that develops within few days
    • Hypotension and shock
    • Severe hypoglycemia
    • Lactation failure

GH deficiency is very common in Sheehan’s syndrome because somatotrophs are located in the lower and lateral regions of the pituitary gland, and are most likely to be damaged by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary.

questions.text: Renal arterial hypertension leads to _______
questions.solution:
Renal arterial hypertension leads to high renin hypertension.

Critical levels of stenosis lead to a reduction in perfusion pressure that :

  • Activates the renin-angiotensin system(a key step in the development of renovascular hypertension)
  • Reduces sodium excretion
  • Activates sympathetic adrenergic pathways

Renovascular hypertension can be treated with agents that block the renin-angiotensin system and other drugs that modify these pressor pathways.

The causes of low renin hypertension are as follows:

  • Low renin essential hypertension (LREH)
  • Primary aldosteronism (eg: Conn syndrome)
  • Liddle syndrome
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor mutation
  • Glucocorticoid resistance
  • Gordon syndrome
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)

questions.text: In a patient with hemophilia A, how much can infusion of one unit of factor VIII/kg increase the plasma levels of factor VIII?
questions.solution:
One unit of factor VIII/kg body weight increases the plasma levels of factor VIII levels by 2%. Therefore, for a rise in 1 % in the plasma, half unit/ kg will be required, that is 0.5 units/kg.

It is used in the treatment of hemophilia. One unit of FVIII is the amount of FVIII in 1 mL of plasma.

The dose required for replacement is calculated as :

  • Factor VIII dose = (Target factor VIII levels - baseline factor VIII levels) x bodyweight x 0.5 units/ kg
  • Factor IX (IU) = (Target FIX levels – FIX baseline levels) x bodyweight (kg) x 1 unit/kg

Cryoprecipitate is used when factor concentrates are not available. Each bag of cryoprecipitate contains 80 IU of Factor VIII.

Blood components Composition Indications
Factor VIII concentrates Factor VIII Hemophilia A
Factor IX concentrates Factor IX Hemophilia B
Cryoprecipitate

Fibrinogen

Factor VIII

VWF

Fibrinogen deficiency, Factor XIII deficiency, von Willebrand disease
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fibromuscular dysplasia is false?

choices.text: Most common histologic subtype is medial fibroplasia
Femoral artery is the limb artery most likely to be affected
The lesions of fibromuscular dysplasia are frequently bilateral tend to affect more distal portions of the renal artery

questions.solution:
The iliac arteries are the limb arteries most likely to be affected by fibromuscular dysplasia.

The histologic classification of fibromuscular dysplasia:

  • Intimal fibroplasia (also classified as focal)
  • Medial dysplasia (multifocal)
  • Adventitial hyperplasia

Medial dysplasia is subdivided into:

  • Medial fibroplasia (most common histologic subtype)
  • Perimedial fibroplasia
  • Medial hyperplasia.

Medial fibroplasia is the most common type

It is more common in females. The lesions of fibromuscular dysplasia are frequently bilateral and it tend to affect more distal portions of the renal artery.

String of beads appearance is seen in angiography.

Clinical conditions in which String of pearls or string of beads sign is seen:

  • Fibromuscular dysplasia
  • Varicose bronchiectasis
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  • Linear IgA disease
  • Small bowel obstruction

questions.text: Dawn phenomenon is clinically suspected when a patient shows which of the following findings?

choices.text: Early morning hyperglycemia with hypoglycemia at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hyperglycemia with normal blood glucose levels at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with hyperglycemia at 3 am

questions.solution:
Dawn phenomenon refers to normal blood glucose levels at 3 am followed by early morning hyperglycemia.

This occurs due to an early morning surge in plasma growth hormone and cortisol levels, which have an insulin-antagonistic action. In normal individuals, this is countered by increased early morning insulin secretion. However, in diabetic patients, insulin secretion is disrupted which results in the unopposed action of growth hormone. Hence, there will be resulting hyperglycemia.

Related Pearl: Dawn Phenomenon and Somogyi Phenomenon

 

Dawn phenomenon

Somogyi phenomenon

Features

Early morning hyperglycaemia

Early morning hyperglycaemia

 

Normal blood glucose levels at 3 am

Hypoglycaemia at 3 am

Mechanism

Early morning surge in growth hormone and cortisol which causes hyperglycemia

Excessive night basal insulin dose > hypoglycemia in middle of night > triggers the release of counterregulatory hormones which causes hyperglycemia.

Treatment

Increase nighttime long-acting insulin dose

Decrease night time long-acting insulin dose

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with shortness of breath. He reports walking slower than his peers due to breathlessness. He has had two hospitalizations for similar complaints this year. His post-bronchodilator PFTs are FEV1/FVC < 0.55 and FEV1 55%.  Under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
This patient belongs to moderate COPD, group E category.

The severity of COPD assessed by the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) is classified as:

GOLD Stage

Severity

II

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

III

Severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

IV

Very severe

FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

 

According to GOLD 2023 guidelines, COPD patients are classified into Group A, B, or E based on the severity of dyspnoea, frequency of exacerbations and hospitilization. Dyspnoea may be assessed using the modified MRC Dyspnoea scale or COPD Assessment Test (CAT score)

>=2 moderate exacerbations or >=1 leading to hospitalisation

Group E:
                         LABA+LAMA

consider LABA+LAMA+ICS* if blood eosinophil count >=300

 

0 or 1 moderate exacerbation (not leading to hospital admissions)

Group A: mMRC 0-1, CAT<10

                Bronchodilator

Group B: mMRC >=2, CAT >=10

          LABA + LAMA*

* single inhaler therapy maybe more convenient and effective than multiple inhalers

ICS - inhaled corticosteroids
LAMA - Long-acting Muscarinic Antagonists
LABA - Long-acting Beta Agonists

Modified MRC (mMRC) dyspnoea scale:

  • 0- Breathless only with strenuous exercise
  • 1- Breathless when hurrying on a level or walking up a hill
  • 2- Walks slower than peers or has to stop for breath when walking on level
  • 3- Stops for breath after walking about 100m or for a few minutes
  • 4- Breathless at rest

questions.text: An adolescent who is a known case of VSD is brought by his parents with complaints of breathlessness on exertion which is gradually progressive, bluish discoloration, and swelling of toes and fingers. Investigations showed features suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following is not a part of the condition?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario along with the development of pulmonary hypertension is seen in Eisenmenger’s syndrome and predominant right to left shunt (not left to right shunt) is seen here.

Gradual onset of cyanosis, dyspnoea, fatigue, and in later stages, heart failure, chest pain, headaches, syncope, and hemoptysis in a setting of congenital acyanotic heart disease, are signs and symptoms of Eisenmenger’s syndrome.

Reversal of the shunt at the level of atria/ventricles/patent ductus arteriosus due to irreversible pulmonary vascular obstructive changes is defined as Eisenmenger’s syndrome.

Features of pulmonary hypertension in Eisenmenger physiology: Right ventricular heave, narrow split S 2 with a loud pulmonic component.

Chest X-ray showing prominent pulmonary artery and right ventricle, peripheral pruning of pulmonary vessels.

ECG shows features of right ventricular hypertrophy, with spiked P waves.

Treatment: Calcium channel blockers, prostacyclin, and it's analog treprostinil and lung transplantation.

questions.text:
The investigations of a male truck driver are given below. Which of the following is he unlikely to present with?
  • VDRL - positive
  • FTA-ABs - Antibodies to T. pallidum present 
  • MRI spine - areas of focal inflammation seen in the dorsal column
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of tabes dorsalis. It presents with loss of reflexes in lower limbs, not hyperreflexia.

Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts. It is seen in tertiary syphilis. It primarily involves the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and dorsal roots.

It presents with the following clinical features:

  • Loss of reflexes in lower limbs 
  • Romberg's sign
  • Bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils - accommodation reflex present, pupillary reflex absent 
  • Loss of position sense and vibration
  • Stabbing/pricking pain in the legs - this is fleeting or repetitive
  • Ataxia of the legs and gait disturbances
  • Paresthesias
  • Bladder disturbances 
  • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting - visceral crisis 

Note: Diabetic polyradiculopathy may simulate tabes.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Which of the following findings will you not expect to see in a patient with SIADH?

choices.text: Normal serum urea and creatinine levels

questions.solution:
SIADH does not cause hypernatremia. SIADH is the most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia. 

The excess ADH secreted leads to the gain of water in the body. This stimulates baroreceptors to release atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). ANP leads to the loss of water and salt in the urine, leading to urine sodium level of > 20 mEq/L in these patients. Thus, the level of water reaches a steady state (euvolemia) but the urinary loss of sodium continues to occur, giving rise to hyponatremia.

SIADH is characterized by low levels of uric acid, normal blood pressure, and normal urea and creatinine levels.

SIADH is diagnosed based on the following criteria (Bartter-Schwartz criteria):

1. Reduced serum osmolality
2. Urine osmolality > Serum osmolality
3. Clinical euvolemia
4. Increased levels of urinary sodium
5. Absence of other causes of hyponatremia like pituitary, renal, adrenal, thyroid or liver diseases.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with Crohn’s disease presents with red tender swellings on the lower leg as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of erythema nodosum seen in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). 

Erythema nodosum is a dermatologic manifestation of IBD. It is seen in both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. It manifests as tender erythematous nodules on the anterior surface of the lower legs, ankles, thighs, and arms.

Option A: Pyoderma gangrenosum is a dermatological manifestation of IBD. It begins as pustular lesions which then ulcerate with necrotic foci and exudation.

Option C: Sweet’s syndrome is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis, seen in ulcerative colitis.

Option D: Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, often seen in immunocompromised patients. It presents as pustules/vesicles which progress to necrotic ulcers.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals a pH of 7.55, pCO2- 54 mmHg, and HCO3- 40 mEq/L. What is the underlying disorder?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic alkalosis.

Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response.

Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response:

On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3-

In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L)

Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L

Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 =  12 mmHg

Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg.

As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

questions.text: Which of the following would be elevated in patients with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is associated with elevated levels of fibrinogen. 

CKD is a pro-inflammatory state characterized by altered levels of acute-phase reactants (APR) 

  • Elevated levels of positive APR like CRP and fibrinogen (associated with high ESR).
  • Reduced levels of negative APR like albumin and fetuin.

questions.text: False about gastrointestinal stromal tumor is

choices.text: Originates from interstitial cells of Cajal
Most common symptom is abdominal mass

questions.solution:
Most common symptom of GIST– bleeding.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor:

  • Most common mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC).
  • Stomach is the most common site.
  • Almost all GISTs express
    • c-KIT (CD117)
    • PDGF receptor A
    • CD34
  • Most common symptom – bleeding
  • Investigation of choice for primary – CT scan.
  • Investigation of choice for recurrent GIST – PET-CT.
  • Route of metastasis – hematogenous.
  • Treatment: Resection with negative margin.
  • Chemotherapy with imatinib, sunitinib.
  • Prognosis – mainly depends on tumor size.

questions.text: Most common malignant brain tumour of childhood is?
questions.solution:
The most common malignant brain tumour of childhood age group is Medulloblastoma.

Medulloblastoma :

  • Primitive neuroectodermal tumor is the most common type of medulloblastoma.
  • Most occur in the first decade of life, but there is a second peak around age 30.
  • It is the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor.
  • They are usually midline.
  • Most occur in the cerebellum and present with symptoms of increased ICP.
  • Histologic characteristics : densely packed small round cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm, generally not encapsulated.
  • Frequently disseminate within the CNS
  • Should undergo surgical resection followed by radiation therapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text:
The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
  1. Glasgow coma scale
  2. Respiratory Rate
  3. Pulse Rate
  4. Systolic BP
  5. Mechanism of Injury
questions.solution:
The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient.

Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

The score range is 0–12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury. 

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A resident while assisting a case of laparoscopic hernia repair observes the surgeon dissect certain anatomical landmarks to expose the triangle of doom. Which of the following does not form a boundary of this triangle?
questions.solution:
Cooper’s ligament does not form the boundary of the triangle of doom.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: Name  the instrument given below is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Czerny's retractor. Czerny’s Retractor is a double-ended retractor used to retract wound edges for intermediate-type procedures. One end has a blade with a lip which helps to retract without the edge slipping. The other end has two prongs and helps to retract the ends of an incision.

Option A: Morris Retractor is a big retractor which is useful for giving a maximum exposure in large incisions such as those used in the abdomen. It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision (by pulling firmly in that direction); so is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Option C: Double hook Retractor is used:

  • To retract skin flap for excision of sebaceous cyst.
  • During venesection for retraction of skin.
  • During tracheostomy for retraction of skin and thyroid isthmus.

Option D: Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

Deaver's Retractor:
