Morris retractor:

Czerny’s retractor:

questions.text: An elderly paraplegic patient admitted to a nursing home, developed an ulcer on her gluteal region. All of the following are true regarding the management of this patient except:

choices.text: Diet and nutritional support should aim to establish a positive nitrogen balance
Following debridement, exposure of the wound is recommended
Tensor fascia lata flap with an intact nerve supply may be used for covering the defect
Frequent change in position and air mattresses can help in preventing further sores

questions.solution:
The given image is that of a grade 3 bedsore. A grade 3 pressure sore requires dressing following debridement.

Preoperative management involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure. Alginates, foams, hydrocolloids, hydrogels are other options that are available.

The aim of surgery is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flaps that include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included (e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh).

Nutritional optimization with high caloric and protein diet should be done to establish a positive nitrogen balance. Frequent changes in position and air mattresses can also help in preventing further sores.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alician blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
It is a reversible cell adaptation

questions.solution:
Mucus-secreting goblet cells ( not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus, as there is intestinal metaplasia of esophagus. Foveolar cells are the mucus-secreting cells in the stomach.

Barrett esophagus :

  • It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus (normal squamous epithelium is replaced by columnar cells).
  • It occurs due to chronic irritation of esophagus eg. GERD (Gastroesophageal reflux disease).
  • As the esophageal epithelium is not capable of handling the gastric acid, it changes to the columnar type, which is seen in the intestine (it can tolerate acid effects). Hence the mucus secreting goblet cells are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.
  • Alician blue is used in the staining of the biopsy specimen, as it stains the goblet cells. Mucicarmine is the specific stain.
  • As all the metaplasia are reversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible. Whereas only 0.2 to 1% of Barrett's esophagus leads to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following are not true regarding external hemorrhoids?
  1. Painful 
  2. Self-curing
  3. Banding is preferred
  4. Covered by squamous epithelium
  5. Commonly located at 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions in the anal canal
questions.solution:
External hemorrhoids are painful, self-curing and covered by squamous epithelium. The branches of the superior rectal vein, located at 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions in the anal canal are common sites for internal hemorrhoids. Banding is preferred for internal hemorrhoids. 

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth muscle fibres, and elastic connective tissue. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal Hemorrhoids 
  • External Hemorrhoids

Note: Repeated thrombosis leads to a semi-ripe black currant appearance of external hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done

questions.text: A newborn infant is diagnosed with a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Circumcision is avoided in these patients
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Usually associated with a ventral deformity of the erect penis
Does not cause obstruction in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
The ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed ("hooded prepuce") in hypospadias.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of a ventrally (underside of penis or perineum) placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis).

Types of hypospadias (according to meatal location):

  • Anterior (Distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (Proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

Note:

In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias because the foreskin may be used later for reconstruction.

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A patient is referred for the evaluation of severe right-sided abdominal pain. Abdominal X-ray appears normal, and a USG revealed the presence of a 6mm renal stone. Which of the following stones is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario since the stone is radiolucent, it is most likely to be uric acid stone.

Uric acid stones are preferentially formed in acidic urine. It is commonly associated with disorders of purine metabolism such as gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. On microscopic examination, the crystals appear as glass shards.

Patients with recurrent uric acid stones are treated with Allopurinol.

Note: 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque, while 80% of gall bladder stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Radiolucent Renal Stones

Radiolucent Renal Stones

Mnemonic: X UTI

  • Xanthine
  • Uric Acid (most common)

Drug induced renal stones

  • Triamterene
  • Indinavir

questions.text: Most common organ that herniates in Morgagni’s hernia is ______
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the most common herniating structure in a Morgagni hernia.

Morgagni Hernia:

  • A hernia in the anterior part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments
  • The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

Morgagni hernia:

questions.text: What is the most common post-operative complication that may arise in patients who undergo an appendectomy ?
questions.solution:
Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication of appendectomy.

Related Pearl: Complications of Appendicectomy

  • Wound infection: 5–10%
  • Intra-abdominal abscess: 8%
  • Post operative ileus
  • Respiratory complications
  • Venous thrombo-embolism
  • Portal pyemia- septicemia in portal venous system, can lead to hepatic abscess.
  • Adhesive intestinal obstruction: 1–3% (MC late post op complication)
  • Fecal fistula
  • Port site hernias.
  • Appendico-cutaneous fistula or appendico-vesical fistula: rare
  • Mortality after appendicectomy is less than 1%

questions.text: A patient has the catheter shown below inserted for draining a large liver abscess. All of the following statements are true except:

choices.text: It is a self retaining catheter
It may be introduced into the urethra to relieve bladder retention
It can be placed percutaneously through an existing nephrostomy

questions.solution:
A Malecot catheter is never introduced per-urethrally.

It is a self-retaining catheter with an umbrella or flower tip. It contains sulfur, hence is radio-opaque. It can be sterilized by boiling.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Pyonephrosis
  • Cabot’s nephrostomy
  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Cholecystotomy
  • Infected pseudocyst of pancreas
  • Amoebic liver abscess
  • Gastrostomy.

questions.text: You are assisting in a modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following steps will not be done by the operating surgeon during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss).

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A patient is recovering from a spinal shock after a fall from height. Which of the following is the first reflex that you will expect to reappear in him?
questions.solution:
Bulbocavernosus reflex is the first reflex to return after the spinal shock has resolved.

It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis in males and applying pressure to the clitoris or pulling the Foleys catheter in females. Any of these will lead to anal sphincter contraction.

Spinal shock is a condition of transient physiologic reflex depression of spinal cord function (motor, sensory, tone, reflexes) below the level of injury. It usually results from a high-impact, direct trauma to the spinal cord. When the level of injury is above T6, it can result in hemodynamic changes such as hypotension and bradycardia (due to loss of sympathetic tone and unopposed parasympathetic function).

The resolution of spinal shock occurs over a period of days to months, when the areflexia slowly transitions to hyperreflexia and spasticity. Reflexes return sequentially rather than simultaneously. The resolution of the somatic component of spinal shock is classically signaled by the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex, a polysynaptic cutaneous spinal reflex (mediated by the conus medullaris) which is then followed by monosynaptic deep tendon reflexes (e.g. ankle jerk).

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with grade 2 splenic injury following blunt trauma to the abdomen. On examination, there are no signs of bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?
questions.solution:
Conservative management is the most appropriate management in this child.

Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) is usually followed in:

  • Stable patients with no active bleeding
  • Patients younger than 55 years of age
  • Patients with grade I, II, III injuries.

Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, has active bleeding, and has grade IV and V splenic injury should be managed by surgery.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the inguinal canal?

choices.text: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wall
Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis
Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis
Internal oblique forms both the anterior and superior walls

questions.solution:
The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, not in the transversus abdominis.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

questions.text: Which of the following values indicate a normal portal venous pressure?
questions.solution:
The normal portal venous pressure is 5 to 10 mmHg. 

Normal portal blood flow is 1 to 1.5 L/minute.

Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the difference between the wedge and free hepatic venous pressure, which is 1 to 5 mmHg.

HVPG interpretation:

  • Normal HVPG is between 1 and 5 mmHg.
  • Portal hypertension is present if the HVPG is ≥6 mmHg.
  • Portal hypertension typically becomes clinically significant when the HVPG is ≥10 mmHg, at which point varices may develop.
  • HVPG ≥12 mmHg, patients are at risk for variceal bleeding and the development of ascites.

questions.text: A cachexic patient with a BMI of 14 was brought to a nursing care facility. Calorie-rich food through a nasogastric tube was started. On day 3 of therapy, the patient suddenly developed a seizure. An ECG showed dysrhythmia. Which of the following findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of refeeding syndrome which results in hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially fatal condition that may occur due to rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

With refeeding, a shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate stimulates insulin release, which results in the cellular uptake of electrolytes, particularly phosphate, magnesium, potassium, and calcium. These electrolyte disorders can result in altered myocardial function, arrhythmias, deteriorating respiratory function, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany, and death.

Severe hyperglycemia may result from blunted basal insulin secretion. It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition but is more common with the latter.

questions.text: What is the most common type of choledochal cyst?
questions.solution:
Type I is the most common type of choledochal cyst (75%).

Choledochal cysts are congenital dilations of the intra- and/or extra-hepatic biliary system. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: All of the following parameters will be included in the assessment of acute pancreatitis using Ranson's criteria, except:
questions.solution:
Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) > 350 IU/L is included in Ranson’s criteria, not 250 IU/L.

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding breast carcinoma?

choices.text: Cutaneous oedema in inflammatory carcinoma is the result of blockage of the sub-dermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells
Mucinous carcinomas are usually hormone negative
Calcifications  are frequently associated with ductal carcinoma in situ
Lobular carcinoma in situ is multi centric and bilateral

questions.solution:
Mucinous carcinoma is usually hormone-positive (90%). It is also called colloid carcinoma. It is a low-grade tumor with a good prognosis. It typically presents as a bulky mass in the elderly. 

Option A: Pathologic hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma is a painful, swollen breast, which is warm with cutaneous edema due to blockage of subdermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells.

Option C: Calcification is usually associated with ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). It is the most common malignancy detected in screening mammograms.

Option D: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is mainly multicentric (sometimes multifocal) and bilateral.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is least likely to be seen in a patient with an intestinal type of gastric cancer?

choices.text: Loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene
Under expression of transforming growth factor α
Loss of heterozygosity at the bcl-2 gene

questions.solution:
In the intestinal type of gastric cancer, several growth factors may be overexpressed, including transforming growth factor α, the epidermal growth factor, and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).

Molecular pathologies seen in Intestinal type:

  • Mutation or loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene or in β-catenin
  • Inactivation of p53
  • Loss of heterozygosity at the BCL-2 gene
  • Microsatellite instability

Molecular pathologies seen in diffuse-type: 

  • Mutation of E- cadherin
  • Inactivation of p53

Related Pearl: Lauren Classification System of gastric carcinoma

Intestinal(type l)

 Diffuse (type ll)

Environmental

 Familial

Gastric atrophy, intestinal metaplasia

  Blood type A
Men > women Women > Men
Increasing incidence with age Younger age group
Gland formation Poorly differentiated, signet ring cells 
Hematogenous spread Transmural, lymphatic spread

Microsatellite instability

APC gene mutations

 Decreased E-cadherin
p53, p16 inactivation p53, p16 inactivation

questions.text: A patient with a leg injury was treated with a skin graft as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this type of skin graft?

choices.text: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
Healing with abnormal pigmentation are more common.
Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand the surface area that can be covered but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance.

Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin split grafts have a low primary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, they tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability.

Type of graft Split-thickness graft Full-thickness graft
Composition Epidermis + part of the dermis Epidermis + full dermis
Cosmetic appearance Relatively poor Good (texture and pigmentation are better matched)
Graft take/survival High chance of survival Poor (long healing time and vascularization)
Contraction Lesser primary contraction and more secondary contraction More primary contraction and lesser secondary contraction
Use Can cover large areas of defects For areas where least contraction (finger) or best cosmesis (face) is desired

The image given below shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the fibrolamellar variant of HCC?

choices.text: Recurrences are seen despite better prognosis
Occur under the age of 35 years
Not commonly associated with chronic hepatitis B infection

questions.solution:
Fibrolamellar variant of HCC is not commonly associated with liver cirrhosis.

Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive variant (<5%) of HCC. They occur under the age of 35 years, without any gender predilection or identifiable predisposing conditions. 

It usually presents as a single large, hard 'scirrhous' tumor. The tumor is well-demarcated, encapsulated, and may have a central fibrotic area. Histology shows large polygonal cells embedded in a fibrous stroma forming lamellar structures.

Fibrolamellar HCC has a better prognosis compared to HCC due to high resectability, but recurrences are seen despite this. Lymph node metastasis may be seen.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and fibrolamellar carcinoma

No gender predilection

55 years

25 years

Tumor 

Invasive

 Well circumscribed

Resectability

<25%

50%–75%

Cirrhosis

90%

5%

AFP positive

80%

5%

Hepatitis B positive

65%

5%

questions.text: All the following statements are true regarding missed abortion except:

choices.text: Dead foetus is seen on USG
Size of uterus corresponds to period of amenorrhoea

questions.solution:
Size of uterus is smaller than the period of amenorrhoea in case of missed abortion.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.

The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: Identify the obstetric grip performed in the picture.
questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is Pelvic grip.

Obstetric grips (Leopold maneuvers):

Leopold Grip Importance
First Fundal To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/Umbilical To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlick 

To know presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth  Pelvic

To know the location of the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis. 

If the presenting part has already descended into the pelvis – this is not possible anymore

questions.text: For effective protection after unprotected intercourse , one single tab of Levonorgestrel 0.75mg  has already been taken. When should the next dose be taken ?
questions.solution:
For emergency contraception levonorgestrel is used, 0.75 mg initially, followed by another 0.75mg 12 hour later.

Emergency(Post coital) contraceptives:

  • It can be started upto 5 days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse but greatest  protection occurs if it is given within 72 hours of unprotected sex.
  • Levonorgestrel 1.5mg single dose is the method of choice.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Prevents ovulation
  • Prevents fertilization
  • Prevents implanatation by affecting endometrial lining.

Methods of Emergency contraception

Drug Dose
Levonorgestrel 0.75mg stat and after 12 hours
Etinyl estradiol 50μg + Norgestrel 0.25 mg 2 tab stat and 2 tab after 12 hours
Conjugated estrogen 15mg BD x 5 days
Ethinyl Estradiol 2.5mg BD X 5 days
Copper IUD's

Insertion within 5-7 days after accidental unprotected exposure.

Not suitable for rape victims
Centchroman 2 tablets(60 mg) to be taken twice at an interval  of 12 hours within 24 hours of intercourse.
Ulipristal 30 mg within 72 hours

questions.text: Which is the HPV serotype most commonly associated with carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV 16 is the most common type associated with carcinoma cervix.

Associations between human papilloma virus (HPV) serotypes and carcinoma cervix:

  • Most common serotype - HPV 16
  • Most malignant serotype - HPV 18
  • Most specific serotype - HPV 18
  • Most common serotype associated with
    • Squamous cell carcinoma - HPV 16
    • Adenocarcinoma - HPV 18

Cancers caused by HPV:

  • Male - penile, oral, anal
  • Female - cervix, vagina, vulva

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of the paramesonephric duct?
questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is not derived from the paramesonephric duct. It is a remnant of the mesonephric/ Wolffian duct.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.

This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument that is commonly used in a dilatation and curettage procedure.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Hegar's double-ended dilator which is used to dilate the cervix in dilation and curettage procedure. 

Pratt dilator is also a double-ended dilator but has a more linear shape as compared to the curved Hegar's dilators. The image given below shows a Pratt dilator.

 

Option A: Hawkin dilator is a single-ended dilator. The image given below shows a Hawkin dilator.

 

Option C: Bakes rosebud dilator is a single-ended dilator used to dilate the urethra. It is called so since its tip is similar to a rosebud. The image given below shows a Bakes dilator.

 

Option D: Fenton dilator is also double-ended but it has a notch in the middle. The image given below shows a Fenton dilator.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the gynecology OPD for a routine Pap smear. The histopathology slide is shown below. Identify the cell marked as "A".
questions.solution:
The cell marked A is the superficial cell. 

ACOG guidelines recommend cervical exfoliative cytology every 3 years starting 21 years as screening for cervical cancer.

The image below shows a superficial cell (a) and an intermediate cell (b):


The image below shows parabasal cells (marked by black arrows):

 

Koilocytes are epithelial cells that contain eccentric, hyperchromatic, moderately enlarged nucleus that is displaced by large perinuclear vacuole. It is a feature of HPV infection.

Related Pearl: Cytohormonal study of the vaginal epithelium

Layer Cell characteristics Hormones Age of the woman
Parabasal and basal Small, round and basophilic with large nuclei Lack of hormonal activity

Childhood until puberty

Menopause with atrophy
Intermediate cells

Transparent and basophilic (blue-green) with vesicular nuclei

 Progesterone, Androgen, Corticosteroid 

Pregnancy

At an early transition of  menopause
Superficial cells Large cells with a pyknotic nucleus, acidophilic on staining Estrogen

Reproductive period

Preovulatory phase

Note: Malignant cells contain less cytoplasm, and hyperchromatic nuclei which are variable in size.

questions.text: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100 mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes. 

First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity, neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia.

First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy:

  • Insulin
  • Glyburide 
  • Metformin

questions.text: An ultrasound was done on a pregnant Rh-negative patient  to screen for hydrops fetalis. What is the earliest sign that may be seen on USG?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of hydrops fetalis on a USG is scalp edema. Subcutaneous scalp edema is also known as the Halo sign. 

Other USG signs include:

  • Ascites
  • Pleural effusion 
  • Pericardial effusion 
  • Typical position termed as Buddha's position   

The image below shows skin thickening at the level of the fetal skull, on ultrasonography:

questions.text: A sexually active woman presented to a rural PHC with itching over the vulval region for a year. On examination, multiple lesions were noted over the vulva. Biopsy revealed cellular abnormality without stromal invasion involving the entire thickness of the vulva. What is the likely degree of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding of cellular abnormality involving the entire thickness of the vulva is suggestive of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) 3.

Degrees of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN): 

Degree Cellular abnormality  Other features
VIN 1 Limited to the basal layer Lower 1/3rd of the vulval epithelium is involved
VIN 2

Basal & intermediate layer

Lower 2/3rd of vulval epithelium  is involved

Commonly associated with HPV
VIN 3

Entire thickness of the vulval epithelium is involved

No vascular/ lymphatic invasion

 2 types:

  • Young patients - HPV +ve, multiple lesions, 90% regress
  • Elderly patients - HPV –ve, single lesion, associated with lichen sclerosis, often progresses to invasive cancer

questions.text:
Endometriosis is seen in
  1. Peritoneum
  2. Liver
  3. Spleen
  4. Pancreas
  5. Brain
questions.solution:
Endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Note: Endometriosis is seen rarely in the brain and pancreas.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman with a history of pre-eclampsia presents at 24 weeks of gestation for an antenatal check-up. You decide to evaluate her risk of developing pre-eclampsia in the present pregnancy. Which of the following results is not an indicator?

choices.text: Absence of diastolic notch on Doppler
High resistance index in uterine artery Doppler in the second trimester
Presence of free fetal DNA in maternal serum

questions.solution:
In this above scenario, the absence of a diastolic notch at 24 weeks on Doppler is not a predictor of pre-eclampsia.

In normal pregnant women, a diastolic notch in the uterine artery disappears by 24 weeks. Thus, a persistent diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks is predictive of preeclampsia.

 Predictors of preeclampsia:

  • Free fetal DNA in maternal plasma
  • Diastolic notch present in uterine artery flow between 22-24 weeks (high resistance index in the second trimester)
  • Average MAP >90 mmHg

Predictors no longer used include:

  • Hemoconcentration
  • Elevated fibronectin
  • Increase in uric acid levels
  • Hypocalciuria - calcium in urine <12mg/dl in 24 h
  • Increased homocysteine levels
  • Roll-over test - screening test is done between 28-32 weeks.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. On CT scan, a bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and liver capsule involvement was seen. What stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Stage 3 ovarian cancer is a unilateral or bilateral ovarian tumor with pelvic lymph node and/or regional lymph node involvement and liver capsule involvement.

Grading of ovarian cancer:

  • Grade 1 - well-differentiated cancers have cells that closely resemble normal cells and are less likely to spread or recur.
  • Grade 2 - moderately differentiated cancer cells. 
  • Grade 3 - poorly differentiated cancers show increasing abnormality of appearance compared to normal cells. They are also more likely to spread and recur. 

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: Which of the following image shows the Duncan method?
questions.solution:
Image B shows the Duncan method of placental separation. 
 

Comparison between two types of placental separation methods:

Schultze method Duncan method
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

Brandt Andrew's method or controlled cord traction is a manoeuvre of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labour. 

One hand grasps the umbilical cord while the other is placed on the mother's abdomen with the fingers over the anterior surface of the uterus. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backwards and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord.

Type III placenta previa is a type of incomplete or partial central placenta previa. Here, the placenta covers the internal os partially i.e. it covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated.

questions.text: A patient with uterine prolapse and urethrocele has weakness in the superficial and deep perineal muscles. What level of support is lost here?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, level 3 supports including the superficial and deep perineal muscles are lost. This causes urethrocele.

DeLancey's levels of support are used to describe the supports of the genital organs.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 1.9 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a circumvallate placenta. The membranes at the periphery are thickened and consist of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

Normally, the chorionic plate and basal plates are of the same size. In conditions of extrachorial placentation, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:

  • Circummarginate placenta -  In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage. 
  • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are:
    • Preterm delivery
    • Abortions
    • IUGR
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Retained placenta and membranes

Option A: Placenta succenturiata has one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins.

Options B & D: Placenta marginata or circummarginate placenta - a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

questions.text: All of the following findings would satisfy the Amsel criteria except:
questions.solution:
Abundant polymorphs are not included in Amsel’s criteria. Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to the alteration of normal vaginal flora. It is not an inflammation. Hence, only a few polymorphs are seen on saline microscopy.

Amsel’s criteria are used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes:

  1. A homogenous vaginal discharge
  2. A vaginal pH of > 4.5
  3. An amine-like odor on adding KOH (Whiff test)
  4. Presence of clue cells

If three out of the above-mentioned four criteria are positive, then a diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis is made.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of unprotected intercourse 2 days ago. Which of the following will you prescribe as a single dose contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg can be used as a single dose emergency contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in interval between coitus and drug intake.

LNG prevents ovulation and makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation. The failure rate is 1.1%. If pregnancy occurs as a result of contraceptive failure, the risk of ectopic pregnancy increases but it is not teratogenic.

Advantages of LNG:

  • No oestrogen and its associated side effects
  • Can be used in hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic patients
  • Suitable for lactating woman
  • Can be given up to 120 hours after the unprotected intercourse
  • Single-dose therapy 

Contraindications of LNG:

  • Liver disease
  • Thrombophlebitis
  • Migraine
  • Galactose allergy - as the tablet contains lactose

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the modified WHO partogram?

choices.text: Right side of alert line indicates immediate referral to First Referral Unit (FRU)
Alert and action line are separated by a difference of 4 hours
Each small square in partogram is equal to 1 hour
Partograph recording should be started once the cervical dilatation reaches 4 cm

questions.solution:
Each small square in a modified WHO partogram is equal to 30 minutes. Each small square in a composite WHO partogram is equal to 1 hour.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of dribbling of urine from the vagina during micturition. She has a history of obstructed labor. Methylene blue 3 swab test is done, and the lowest swab gets stained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a urethrovaginal fistula.

Urethrovaginal fistulas have the following clinical features:

  • Continent and dry at rest
  • Urinary dribbling during micturition
  • Fistulous opening is seen on per speculum examination

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a catheter.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive UPT. Her past obstetric history was significant for 2 mid-trimester abortions. On USG, cervical length was 20 mm and no bulging membranes were seen.  What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cervical incompetence. It can be managed with prophylactic cervical cerclage done between 12 and 14 weeks of gestation.

Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation. It should only be done when there is bulging of membranes through the dilated cervix. 

Investigations for cervical incompetence:

  • In interconceptional period - 
    • Passage of number 6 - 8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain
    • Funnel-shaped shadow in premenstrual hysterocervicography
  • During pregnancy -
    • Per speculum examination showing cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
    • USG revealing cervical length <2.5 cm and funnelling of internal os >1 cm

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with a mass bulging into the vagina, difficult intercourse, and back pain. She has a history of hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, you observe that the vaginal vault is protruding outside the introitus. What is the best management in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of vault prolapse. Sacrospinous colpopexy is the gold standard management for vault prolapse. 

Vault prolapse presents with pelvic or back pain, the descent of the vault through the vagina, difficulties in intercourse, and difficulty in walking due to the mass. It is commonly associated with a cystocele or a rectocele. 

It can be prevented by identifying and repairing an enterocele and by attaching the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments to the vault during a hysterectomy. 

Vault prolapse is managed as follows: 

  • If the patient is fit for abdominal surgery: Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, i.e., uterosacral suspension
  • If the patient is not fit for abdominal surgery: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation/colpopexy - the gold standard 
  • Laparoscopic colpopexy
  • If the patient does not want to retain sexual function:
    • Colpocleisis
    • Le Fort's repair 
  • Anterior colporrhaphy in case of cystocele
  • Posterior colporrhaphy in case of rectocele
  • If the patient is unfit for surgery, ring pessaries can be tried 
  • Posterior intravaginal slingplasty

Note: Kelly's repair and Burch colposuspension are done to manage stress incontinence. 

Related Pearl: Degrees of vault prolapse

  • First degree: The vaginal apex is visible at the introitus
  • Second degree: The vault protrudes through the introitus
  • Third degree: The entire vagina is outside the introitus

questions.text: You see a resident use the following instrument to grasp the anterior lip of the cervix in a patient posted for a vaginal hysterectomy. What is this instrument known as?
questions.solution:
The image shows vulsellum forceps. It is used to grasp the cervical lip and steady the cervix during vaginal surgery. It is a long instrument with a gentle curve so that the line of vision is not obstructed.

Option A: Allis forceps can be identified by continuous teeth, equal on both ends. It is used to hold structures with a firm grip.

Option C: Kocher's artery forceps are non-traumatic with a single tooth at the tip. They help in achieving hemostasis by firm pressure.

Option D: Lahey's tissue grasping forceps has teeth similar to dinner forks. They are used to hold fibrous tissue and they give a firm grip without slippage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has come for pre-conceptional counselling. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2 and she is worried about weight gain during pregnancy. How much weight should she gain during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question is obese. The recommended gestational weight gain in such a patient is 5-9 kg. 

Ideally, weight gain should depend on the pre-pregnancy BMI (body mass index) level. The gestational weight gain recommended for each BMI category by the Institute of Medicine (IOM) are as follows: 

Category

BMI (in kg/m2)

Recommended weight gain

Underweight

<18.5

12.5–18 kg

Normal

18.5–24.9

11.5–14 kg

Overweight

25–29.9

7–11.5 kg

Obese

>30

5-9.1 kg

questions.text:
The laparoscopy report of a woman with pelvic inflammatory disease states she has Gainesville stage III PID. Which of the following presentations could have been seen in her?
  1. Acute salpingitis with peritonitis.
  2. Acute salpingitis with no adhesions.
  3. Acute salpingitis with tubo-ovarian complex
  4. Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
  5. Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion
questions.solution:
Gainesville stage III includes two forms of PID - acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex.

Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage as follows:

Stage

Condition 

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - no adhesions 

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge  

Stage III

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess 

Stage V

Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: Metrorrhagia refers to _______

choices.text: Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Regularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on abnormal cyclical bleeding
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding

questions.solution:
Irregularly timed episodes of bleeding superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding are referred to as metrorrhagia.

Menstrual cycle irregularities are as follows:

  • Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs irregularly and at frequent intervals.
  • Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.
  • Amenorrhea indicates the absence of menstruation. 
  • Polymenorrhea indicates frequent episodes of menstruation that occur at intervals of 21 days or lesser. 
  • Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>5 days). 
  • Intermenstrual bleeding refers to bleeding (usually not excessive) that occurs between otherwise normal menstrual cycles.
  • Precocious menstruation is the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.
  • Postcoital bleeding is vaginal bleeding after sexual intercourse.

questions.text: You are inserting Nova-T in a patient for spacing of births. This device contains______.
questions.solution:
Nova-T contains both copper and silver. The addition of the silver increases its effective lifespan.

In copper-carrying devices, copper wire is wrapped around the vertical stem of a polypropylene frame. Some of them have copper wire wrapped around the arms too. Based on the surface area, they are of various types:

  • Copper T 380 A
  • Multiload copper 250
  • Copper T 200
  • Copper 7
  • Copper T 220
  • Nova-T

They are effective for 3–5 years. It is estimated that about 50 mcg of copper is eluted daily in the uterus. Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years. Nova T has a lifespan of 5 years.

questions.text: A teenage girl who recently got diagnosed with PCOS presented with skin lesions on her forehead as shown in the image below. On examination, hirsutism was also noted. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are acne. The drugs used to treat acne and hirsutism in a patient with PCOS are OCPs with cyproterone acetate.

The first step in the management of PCOS is weight reduction. OCPs are the drugs of choice for regularisation of cycles. They are also the drugs of choice for hirsutism and acne. OCPs used for PCOS should contain a 3rd/4th generation progestagen like cyproterone acetate. OCPs induce regular menstrual cycles, lower androgen levels and causes thinning of the endometrium.

Insulin sensitizers like metformin have been found to improve metabolic and gynecologic issues. It acts by reducing the insulin level and reducing hepatic production of glucose (liver neoglycolysis). Other benefits of metformin include improvement in fertility rate and reduction of the total and free testosterone levels. It also increases levels of sex hormone-binding globulin. Metformin is contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease.

Treatment of infertility associated with PCOS is done using ovulation-inducing drugs like letrozole and clomiphene citrate. If medical management fails, surgical options like laparoscopic ovarian drilling can be considered.

Note: 

FOGSI, in 2024, has replaced Letrozole as the first-line drug for induction of ovulation in patients with PCOS. However, the FDA approval for the same is still pending.

 

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: While assessing the Apgar score of the newborns, you would assess and score all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Respiratory effort, not rate is a component of Apgar score.

The Apgar score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn's condition using the 5 parameters explained below. It is performed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth.

  • Color (A, appearance)
  • Heart rate (P, pulse)
  • Response to a catheter in nostril (G, grimace)
  • Muscle tone (A, activity)
  • Respiratory effort (R)

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows discrete tan-colored nodules over the iris called Lisch nodules (pigmented melanocytic hamartomas). They are seen in neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis (TS) and not neurofibromatosis.

The image below shows facial angiofibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease).

Lisch nodules are specifically associated with NF-1 and are usually multiple and bilateral. They are best visualized with a slit lamp examination and don’t cause any visual disturbances.

Other important ocular manifestations in NF-1 include eyelid plexiform neurofibroma, which causes S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture, optic nerve glioma, and spheno-orbital encephalocele due to dysplasia of greater wing of the sphenoid.

NF-1 (von Recklinghausen's disease) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation of the NF-1 gene located on chromosome 17q11.2. NF-1 produces neurofibromin, which acts as a tumor suppressor and a negative regulator of RAS-MAP kinase signaling.

Clinical features of NF-1 include café-au-lait macules, axillary freckling, Lisch nodules,  neurofibromas, and optic gliomas. 
NF-1 is more common than NF2 and typically diagnosed in childhood. NF-2 is rarer but often presents with bilateral acoustic neuroma, juvenile cataract and schwannoma.

The various neurocutaneous syndromes and their ocular manifestations are as follows:

Neurocutaneous syndrome Ocular
manifestations
Neurofibromatosis
type 1

Eyelid plexiform neurofibroma

Optic nerve glioma

Bilateral Lisch nodules

Congenital ectropion uveae

Prominent corneal nerves

Congenital glaucoma

Spheno-orbital encephalocele 
Neurofibromatosis
type 2

Posterior subcapsular cataract

Hamartomas of the
retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and retina
Sturge-Weber syndrome

Choroidal hemangioma

Iris heterochromia

Ipsilateral glaucoma
Tuberous sclerosis

Atypical iris coloboma

Iris hypopigmentation

Retinal astrocytoma
von Hippel-Lindau
syndrome

Retinal hemangiomas

questions.text: Cancer-'The emperor of all maladies spares no one'. Which of the following is the most common childhood malignancy?
questions.solution:
Leukemias are the most common childhood malignancies. Among these, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common, accounting for about 77% of childhood leukemias. 

Most commons in childhood malignancies:

  • Second most common malignancy in childhood: Brain tumor
  • Third most common malignancy in children: Lymphoma
  • Most common solid tumor in children: Brain tumor

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. The child's parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

choices.text: The period of infectivity is 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common complication is pneumonia

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. The most common cause of death is pneumonia (Hecht's giant cell pneumonia).

Measles (rubeola) is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. The infection is spread via droplets, with a secondary attack rate ≥of 90%. The patients are infectious from 4 days before upto 5 days after the appearance of the rash. The rash appears on the 4th day of fever. It starts from the retro auricular region. Koplik spots are pathognomonic.

The most common cause of death is pneumonia. Measles can lead to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) as a late complication.

Measles can be prevented by administering live attenuated, Edmonston–Zagreb strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

1st disease

Measles

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

Rubella

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

Roseola infantum

questions.text: A mother reports to you that her baby is irritable and cries all the time. She has also noticed that her infant sweats excessively while feeding. Which of the following findings noted during the examination would you not include under NADA's major criteria?

choices.text: Grade 2 mid-diastolic murmur at the mitral area
Grade 3 pansystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border

questions.solution:
Wide and variable S2 (Abnormal S2) is not included under Nada's major criteria.

Features of congestive cardiac failure, a grade 3 pansystolic murmur with wide and variable S2, and an MDM at the mitral area suggest a diagnosis of large VSD in this baby.

NADA's criteria for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease:

Major criteria  Minor criteria
Systolic murmur  grade 3 or more Systolic murmur < grade 3
Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2)
Cyanosis Abnormal ECG
Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings
 

Abnormal BP

The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

Pansystolic murmurs are always pathological no matter their intensity.

Short, soft systolic murmurs of intensity <3 are often detected during febrile illnesses, after which they disappear. Such murmurs are called innocent murmurs. Before labeling any murmur as innocent, it should be reassessed after an interval.

questions.text: One of the kids has scribbled all over a newly painted wall inside an Anganwadi. You notice there are some triangles and squares as well, in this "drawing". This child must be older than _______
questions.solution:
The milestones at 5 years of age are:

  • Motor - skips
  • Adaptive - draws triangle
  • Language - asks meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social - dresses and undresses

Related Pearl: Fine motor milestones

 
Age Milestone

6 months
Reaches out for objects with one hand (Unidextrous reach) and transfers objects

12 months Mature pincer grasp

18 months Scribbles and builds a tower of 3 blocks

questions.text: An unbooked primigravida, with no antenatal records, delivers a 2.5kg male baby by normal delivery. While ascertaining the maturity of the child, which of the following would be against a diagnosis of prematurity?
questions.solution:
Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity).

Score Ear
0 Pinna flat and stays folded; no recoil
1 Slightly curved pinna; soft; slow recoil
2 Well-curved pinna; soft but ready recoil
3 Formed & firm, instant recoil
4 Thick cartilage, ear stiff

No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule, and empty scrotum are all physical signs of prematurity in a newborn.

Note:

Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates of diabetic mothers born as a term or even post-term have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the pinna and upper back.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is rushed to the emergency department because of an episode of fits associated with uprolling of eyes and high fever. Kernig’s sign is negative and there are no post-ictal neurological deficits. There is a history of a similar episode when the child had a fever due to gastroenteritis. Which of the following is false regarding this type of seizures?

choices.text: Likelihood of developing epilepsy is low
Associated with temperature of 38°C or higher
Antipyretics reduce the risk of recurrent febrile convulsions
Absence of having a developmental delay

questions.solution:
This is a probable case of febrile seizures due to the presence of high fever, no post-ictal deficits and a negative Kernig's sign ruling out meningitis. Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizure, as the seizure often occurs as the temperature is rising or falling abruptly.

Febrile seizures are seizures that-

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails or in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to be jaundiced. His stools are yellow and urine appears pale straw, he is otherwise well. A provisional diagnosis of breastmilk jaundice is made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Some babies need treatment with phototherapy
It is common in the second week of life

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Breastmilk jaundice is seen in about 2–4% of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding. 

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

It is an early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants. Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth). It is due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. The treatment would include continuing breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

"We haven't stopped breastfeeding even once for treatment of breast milk jaundice in the last 15 years!" states the AIIMS Protocols in Neonatology-2019 (2nd edition; Page no -231)

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-month-old blue baby to your pediatric clinic for the first time. Neonatal records were not available but the mother says that the X-ray of the baby looked like that of a shoe. Which of the following wouldn't you expect in this baby?

choices.text: Large "a" waves in jugular venous pulse

questions.solution:
The given history of the shoe (boot) shaped heart in cyanotic baby is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot and cardiomegaly is not a part of TOF presentation. 

In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiac enlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Any build-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle.

Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results in reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowing deoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle to exit the heart.

Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.

questions.text: Acantholysis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Acantholysis is not seen in bullous pemphigoid as it is associated with subepidermal blistering.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.

Acantholysis is classified as:

Primary

Secondary
Rupture of the desmosome first, forming circular acantholytic cells Ballooning of the keratinocyte first, forming circular acantholytic cells (Tzank cell) 

Seen in: 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Darier's disease
  • Hailey Hailey disease

Seen in:

  • Herpes simplex infections (HSV-1 and 2)
  • Varicella-zoster infections (chickenpox, shingles)

The image below shows acantholysis (note the rounded and free-floating, detached keratinocytes).

questions.text: Which of the following multienzyme complexes catalyzing decarboxylation reactions does not require thiamine as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) does not serve as the coenzyme for isocitrate dehydrogenase. 

Isocitrate dehydrogenase, an enzyme of the citric acid cycle, uses Mg2+ or Mn2+ ions as a coenzyme. 

Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), from vitamin B1, serves as the coenzyme for three multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase - carbohydrate metabolism
  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase - citric acid cycle
  • Branched-chain keto-acid dehydrogenase - metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, valine

Most of these enzymes are involved in carbohydrate metabolism, so thiamine is required in excess during a high carbohydrate diet. TPP also serves as the cofactor for transketolase in the HMP shunt.
